pages.subdeck: Reunion ... mum Rose Barwuah and Manchester City striker Mario Balotelli
pages.headline: Balotelli mum's reunion joy
pages.teaser: MOTHER of the Man City ace says: 'I am happy to see him and he is happy to see me'
pages.byline: By JANE ATKINSON and NICK PISA
pages.articlebody:
THE MUM of Man City ace Mario Balotelli last night told of her joy at being reunited after giving him up as a child.

Relieved Rose Barwuah, 46, added: "I am happy to see him and he is happy to see me."

The Sun told on Sunday how Rose moved from Italy to the tough estate featured in TV's Shameless to be near the striker, 21, in the hope of rekindling their relationship.

Her £120,000-a-week son  who she handed to a rich foster family when he was two  now often shows up in his white Bentley GT at her £550-a-month rented terrace.

Rose said: "Mario has been over to see me a few times, but he doesn't want people to know I'm here. We don't see each other all the time as he has his life and I have mine.

"He's a private person and it's still early days." She added: "I haven't even been to watch him play football here yet, but I'm very proud of him. I'm thrilled, overjoyed to be here."

Rose and daughter Angel, 13, moved to Manchester's Wythenshawe area just before Christmas. Angel now goes to a local school.

Nineteen years ago in Italy, she and hubby Thomas were advised to hand Mario to foster parents  the Balotellis.

The couple were then living in a tiny flat in Brescia  and claimed the Balotellis turned Mario against them.

pages.subdeck: Injunction ... Tulisa Contostavlos
pages.headline: Tulisa ex: Sex tape her idea
pages.teaser: RAPPER MC Ultra  real name Justin Edwards  broke his silence over tape
pages.byline: By EMILY NASH and GARY O'SHEA
pages.articlebody:
THE former boyfriend of Tulisa Contostavlos broke his silence over their infamous sex tape yesterday and insisted it was HER idea.

Rapper MC Ultra  real name Justin Edwards  denied releasing the explicit footage, which shows the X Factor judge in an intimate moment with him.

He also backed a legal ban on the clip and said it should never have been made public.

In a statement read to London's High Court, Edwards, 28, said: "I am disgusted it has been, and regret ever allowing the claimant to persuade me that we should film ourselves."

He maintained he would not have published the clip  adding: "Simply because I would find it ungentlemanly. I was brought up better than that."

After the hearing, Edwards exclusively told The Sun: "I'm just relieved to have a chance to tell my side of the story.

"It can't happen soon enough. I've had to move out of my home and it's been a nightmare for my family.

"I just want this sorted out so I can move on with my life."

Last Friday Edwards was slapped with a £100,000 claim for damages for alleged breach of privacy and confidentiality by Tulisa, who accused him of leaking the six-minute video.

But yesterday he suggested the footage  published online last week  was filmed on the N-Dubz star's phone and denied he'd ever owned it.

His statement read: "I simply do not, and never have, possessed the film referred to."

Yet Tulisa's QC Desmond Browne told Mr Justice Tugendhat the singer had been "the victim of a vindictive act of betrayal by Mr Edwards  seemingly motivated by personal spite and financial greed".

He called the rapper's denial that he passed on the sex tape "hypocrisy" and "a deceitful representation of the position".

Tulisa, 23, won an injunction last week after the video appeared on the net for downloads.

In a preliminary hearing yesterday Mr Justice Tugendhat extended the ban on anyone using, publishing, communicating or disclosing the clip to any other person.

A date for the next hearing has not yet been set.

pages.subdeck: Scandal ... David Cameron
pages.headline: Chequers in the post
pages.teaser: MULTI-millionaire Tory donors wined and dined by David Cameron in No10 & Chequers
pages.byline: By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor and EMILY ASHTON
pages.articlebody:
SEVENTEEN multi-millionaire Tory donors have been wined and dined by David Cameron in No 10 and Chequers since he became PM, most of them secretly, it emerged last night.

The business and City fat cats handed over a total £23million to boost Conservative coffers.

The party was forced to reveal the embarrassing list as the cash for access scandal engulfing the PM deepened.

In another bruising day for Mr Cameron, Downing Street was pushed into a series of embarrassing U-turns to distance itself from shamed former treasurer Peter Cruddas, who was sacked two days ago.

He was caught by Sunday Times undercover reporters saying big donors to the party could buy time with the PM as well as influence over Government policies.

It emerged yesterday that Mr Cameron used his official country mansion Chequers and No 10 to glad-hand loaded supporters. Chancellor George Osborne also revealed that three Tory donors visited his residence at Dorneywood, Bucks.

They were Lord Feldman, Lord Wolfson and Howard Leigh. All are long-standing friends and visited in a personal capacity.

Only 24 hours earlier, No 10 had insisted the public had NO right to know who the Premier invited to his flat because it was private.

But by 6pm yesterday, the Tories had listed every private lunch or dinner the PM had with donors who gave over £50,000. The occasions include:

A "thank you" dinner in the state rooms of No 10 for party donors after the General Election win in July 2010.

Three private dinners with him and wife Samantha in his No 10 flat between February 2011 and February 2012.

Three lunches at Chequers over the last two years.

In a bid to put the scandal behind him, Mr Cameron again called the Cruddas bragging "completely unacceptable". The PM insisted: "None of these dinners were fundraising dinners and none were paid for by the taxpayer. I have known most of those attending for many years. Peter Cruddas has never recommended anyone to come to dinner in the flat."

Mr Cameron also promised that from now the Tories will publish details of meals attended by donors in Downing Street and Chequers.

The PM also urged Labour leader Ed Miliband to agree a cap on individual political donations of £50,000. He said: "We could take the big money out of politics, once and for all."

In another U-turn, the Tories appointed lawyer and Tory peer Lord Gold to lead an internal party inquiry. The PM's initial choice, Tory chairman and close pal Lord Feldman, was met with howls of derision.

Labour insisted nothing short of a full independent inquiry would do.

Despite denials that donors influenced policy, it emerged yesterday that a big giver wrote a major policy document at No 10's request. Venture capitalist Adrian Beecroft, who gave £593,000 to the party, drew up plans to remove some workers' rights.

Asked whether PM will entertain donors in his private flat in future, a close aide said: "I suspect that there won't be that many. But there's nothing wrong with the PM meeting people who have donated to the party."

In another hurried move, the Government tried to restart stalled cross-party talks on party funding.

Tory MP Matthew Hancock last night asked ex-PMs Tony Blair and Gordon Brown to reveal Labour donors who dined at No 10 and Chequers.

t.newtondunn@the-sun.co.uk



Paul Walsh

THE Chief Executive of drinks giant Diageo donated at least £10,000 to the Tory Party. Mr Walsh is also the Chairman of the Scotch Whisky Association and reportedly owns a herd of South American alpacas.

TORY Party treasurer until October 2010 donated £3,624,452. Owner of spread betting firm City Index and CEO of ICAP, the world's biggest money broker. Is the 62nd richest person in the UK.

CO-TREASURER of Tory Party since March 2012 donated 3,311,850. Made fortune in international metal markets. Runs RedKite Capital management, a hedge fund.

THE co-chair of the Conservative Party donated £74,270. Was made a life peer in 2010 after working on Mr Cameron's leadership campaign. Met the Prime Minister in a college tennis team at Oxford University.

TORY Party treasurer gave at least £1.9million. Known as the "godfather" of UK hedge fund industry. Fortune estimated at £120million. Stepped down as Treasurer three weeks ago but back to replace shamed Peter Cruddas.

DEPUTY Tory Party chairman from 2005 to 2010 donated £4,941,088. Built up huge fortune through deal-making in the City. Appointed lead adviser on a Government review of military bases in Cyprus in 2011.

THE co-founder and senior partner at Cavendish Corporate Finance donated a total of £115,456. He has also served as the senior treasurer of the Conservative Party.

THE co-founder of property developers Argent Group has donated £457,900. He runs a charitable trust with his wife Clara, who is an ex-director of Marks & Spencer. It is a major donor to the National Theatre in London.

DONATED at least £107,500. Has been chairman of GlaxoSmithKline since 2005, retired as Vodafone CEO in 2003. Served on Tax Reform Commission, set up by George Osborne, in 2005.

NEWSPAPER boss donated £23,925 through his Telegraph Media Group to hire a stand annually at the Conservative Party conference. Tory sources said he had to pay via donations under Electoral Commission rules.

Lord Sainsbury

BILLIONAIRE president of supermarket empire Sainsbury's donated £1,050,000. Made a life peer in 1989 for the Tories. Donated £50million to London's National Gallery in 1985 to construct the Sainsbury Wing.

...Meanwhile at Chevening

with Nick Clegg

DEPUTY PM Nick Clegg invited four Lib Dem funders to dine at Chevening, a mansion he shares with William Hague in Kent. They were Richard Duncalf, Rumi Verjee, James Palumbo and Sudhir Choudhrie.



myView

By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor

THINK you've heard the cash for access story before?

You have. Three times this year in one shape or form, dozens over the last decade, thousands over the previous century.

Neither is big money sleaze a Tory disease. Labour and the Lib Dems are in it up to their necks.

So why do British politicians keep on making the same mistakes over and over again?

Despite all their rhetoric about the need for change, it never comes. They do nothing because they're scared nobody likes them.

A cap on big donations  be they from businessmen, unions or charities  would mean parties have to rely on small donations from ordinary people.

Every party secretly fears there are far too few left who trust politicians enough to hand over their hard-earned pennies and stop the parties going bust.

They are right, and it's a vicious circle. Because with every fresh cash for access scandal, the number dwindles even further.

pages.subdeck: Gun victim ... Thusha Kamaleswaran
pages.headline: Gang guilty of shooting five-year-old Thusha
pages.teaser: LITTLE Thusha Kamaleswaran was left paralysed for life after attack in shop
pages.articlebody:
GANG members who left a five-year-old girl paralysed after gunning her down in a shop have been found guilty of GBH.

Nathaniel Grant, Kazeem Kolawole and Anthony McCalla were convicted by a jury at the Old Bailey in London of causing grievous bodily harm to little Thusha Kamaleswaran.

She was shot by the thugs as she played in her aunt's shop in South London in March last year.

The nightmare scenes unfolded in March last year as the trio fired blindly into the Stockwell Food and Wine store.

A bullet hit Thusha in the chest and passed through the seventh vertebra of her spine, leaving her wheelchair-bound for life.

Shopper Roshan Selvakumar was shot in the face in the attack, and has been left with bullet fragments permanently lodged in his head.

Callous Grant, Kolawole and McCalla were looking for a rival gang member when Grant mindlessly opened fire into the shop.

Jurors were told that he would have been able to see Thusha as he fired his second shot.

Dramatic CCTV footage was also shown to the jury from inside the store, where Mr Selvakumar can be seen with blood pouring from his head and Thusha lies slumped on the floor.

The three defendants were found guilty of causing grievous bodily harm with intent to Thusha, now six, and Mr Selvakumar.

They were also convicted of attempted murder of their intended victim Roshaun Bryan.

Prosecutor Edward Brown QC told jurors: "The reality of this shooting may be that, whilst there was an intention to kill the suspected rival gang member, the gunman and his accomplices couldn't have cared less if someone else was shot too."

pages.subdeck: Troll ... student Liam Stacey could be jailed
pages.headline: Muamba Twitter troll could get jail
pages.teaser: STUDENT Liam Stacey warned all options will be considered for sentencing today
pages.articlebody:
A TWITTER troll who mocked stricken footballer Fabrice Muamba when he collapsed on the pitch could be jailed today.

Liam Stacey, 21, has admitted inciting racial hatred after posting vile comments on the microblogging site as the player was being treated.

Muamba, 23, fell to the ground live on TV on March 17 as his Bolton Wanderers team took on Spurs in the FA Cup.

Stacey, a Swansea University biology student, was caught after police were swamped with complaints about his remarks.

The first of his messages began with "LOL. **** Muamba. He's dead!!!"

Other Twitter users then took him to task, which prompted sickening racist comments from Stacey.

Last week he admitted inciting racial hatred when he appeared briefly at Swansea Magistrates' Court.

He was released on conditional bail but warned that all options would be considered when he is sentenced today.

The maximum possible sentence an offender can get for inciting racial hatred is seven years.

Muamba has made an incredible recovery since his heart attack ten days ago and was well enough to watch Match Of The Day over the weekend.

pages.subdeck: Security scare ... Simon Cowell
pages.headline: It's shelf defence
pages.teaser: POLICE found a woman intruder hiding on a SHELF in the music mogul's walk-in wardrobe, it has emerged
pages.byline: By LEIGH HOLMWOOD, Deputy TV Editor
pages.articlebody:
POLICE found a woman intruder on a SHELF in Simon Cowell's wardrobe, it emerged last night.

The Sun revealed yesterday how the X Factor boss was confronted by a female wielding a brick when he rushed to investigate after hearing a noise at his home.

A woman appeared in court yesterday as further details of Saturday night's incident emerged.

Cowell, 52, came face-to-face with the intruder, who was standing on a flat roof shouting and holding a brick above her head after breaking his bathroom window, sources revealed.

The woman is said to have told Cowell's shocked staff: "Simon knows me."

Armed police were called and found her hiding on a shelf 7ft up in Cowell's walk-in wardrobe. They also reported blood stains by the broken window.

It is believed she uncovered details of Cowell's West London home after researching it online.

Cowell tightened his security yesterday, adding extra bodyguards to the team that protect him 24/7. A source said: "It's a shame as he prides himself on being a man of the people, but he just can't take chances."

Leanne Zaloumis, 29, of Catford, South East London, appeared at West London Magistrates Court accused of aggravated burglary. The charge claims she intended to inflict GBH. She spoke only to confirm her personal details as she was remanded in custody until June.

pages.subdeck: Hunt ... yob's e-fit
pages.headline: Racist yob in acid attack on black mum with baby
pages.teaser: THUG squirted acid and snarled: 'You've got dark skin, I can do something about that'
pages.articlebody:
A RACIST thug squirted acid at a black mother and snarled: "You've got dark skin  I can do something about that."

The crop-haired yob struck as the woman pushed her baby in a pram through an underpass.

After making vile sexual and racist comments he came up behind the 29-year-old and splashed her back with the corrosive liquid.

When the African-born mum spun round he squirted her in the chest.

Miraculously he did not hit her in the face and her six-month-old baby was unharmed. But the woman, who is originally from Cameroon, needed skin grafts to burns on her body.

Last night police investigating the attack in Salford, Gtr Manchester, called it "appalling". Det Con Jim Harris said: "The lady was very distressed."

They released an e-fit of the maniac who is about 6ft and in his 40s with blue eyes, a red mark on his bottom lip and a local accent.

pages.subdeck: Incredible figure ... mum-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman
pages.headline: 'Octomom' poses for topless snaps
pages.teaser: MUM-OF-FOURTEEN poses for topless snaps three years after having her octuplets
pages.articlebody:
MUM-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman shows off her incredible post-babies body in these revealing snaps.

Nadya, dubbed "Octomom" after giving birth to octuplets in 2009, happily posed topless for a magazine shoot.

And while she boasts of attracting plenty of admirers with her flat stomach and 34DD boobs, she claims she has been celibate for 13 years  as her children were all conceived through a sperm donor.

She explained: "I get way too much male attention, but I won't date until the octuplets are 18  I live for them now.

"I know a lot of women like male attention, but I'll go out with no make-up on and wear tracksuits, a wig and even a fake pregnancy stomach to put them off."

She added: "I wouldn't rule out a relationship in the future. But now, when men look at me, I look away and they know not to approach me.

"I know I'm beautiful  I don't need a man to tell me that."

Nadya, who lives in California, US, already had six kids  Elijah, now 10, Amerah, nine, Joshua, eight, Aiden, six, and twins Caleb and Calyssa, five, when she claims she decided to have more embryos implanted from the same sperm donor.

And her brood was soon joined by six boys and two girls  Noah, Jonah, Jeremiah, Isiah, Josiah, McCai, Maliah and Nariah, who turned three in January this year.

But amazingly, the 36-year-old says it was no effort at all to get her figure back following her last pregnancy.

She explained: "I just pinged back into shape like a rubber band after the kids  I don't know how I did it.

"I eat like a horse, don't count calories and have never owned a set of scales.

"I gained an entire human when I was pregnant with the octuplets  going from 10st to over 19st  but, two months later, I was a size eight again. Now, I never weigh myself."

pages.headline: Heroes shot dead by traitor
pages.teaser: PAIR were shot and killed this morning at main Nato base in Helmand province
pages.articlebody:
THE two hero soldiers murdered in Helmand yesterday were gunned down by a turncoat Afghan trooper at the main gate to the British HQ.

The traitor opened fire as he tried to trick his way into Our Boys' heavily-fortified headquarters in Lashkar Gah.

He blasted a Royal Marine and a member of the Adjutant General's Corps with his powerful M-16 assault rifle from just THREE YARDS away.

The rogue shooter  who was in full Afghan army uniform  wounded a third Brit before being shot dead by our troops in a rapid firefight.

He was able to get so close to his victims by claiming he had been assigned to provide security for government VIPs arriving from Kabul.

The Taliban said he had been in touch with them and had told them of his intention to kill.

Afghan Army chief Ghulam Farooq Parwani said the traitor had been a soldier for four years. He added: "He got close to the foreign troops and opened fire."

Shocked Defence Secretary Philip Hammond told the Commons: "Our thoughts, as ever, are with the families, for whom this will be a deeply personal tragedy." An urgent inquiry has been launched.

Hours after the Brits were killed an Afghan police officer shot dead a US soldier at a checkpoint in the east of the country.

The shootings are the latest in a series of treacherous attacks in which the Afghan security forces have killed an estimated 79 Nato service personnel and wounded 110 more since 2007.

Armed Forces Minister Nick Harvey said "force protection" was kept under constant review.

A total of 407 British troops have been killed in Afghanistan since 2001.

pages.subdeck: Crisis ... fear the pumps may run dry
pages.headline: Don't panic buy
pages.teaser: AA urged caution as Unite boss Len McCluskey refused to rule out action next month
pages.byline: By KEVIN SCHOFIELD and STEVE HAWKES
pages.articlebody:
MOTORISTS were last night warned not to panic buy petrol after fuel tanker drivers voted to strike  with action possible over EASTER.

The AA urged caution as militant Unite boss Len McCluskey refused to rule out a stoppage next month.

It said: "If we all go out and fill up tomorrow the whole system is not going to cope."

The prospect of pumps running dry followed a ballot of 2,000 drivers at seven distribution firms over terms and conditions. Together, they deliver petrol and diesel to 90 per cent of Britain's 8,706 forecourts. Staff at five companies  around 1,200 drivers  voted to strike.

But one of the firms, Hoyer, said only 215 of 650 drivers were in support. It added: "We believe action is being driven by a small, disaffected group." Hundreds of Army drivers are being trained to transport fuel in a bid to avert the crisis.

But one industry expert said: "Broadly speaking, a strike could stop Britain." Action by drivers, who earn £45,000 on average, would hit petrol stations at Shell, Sainsbury's, Tesco, BP and Esso. Energy

Secretary Ed Davey said: "The union should be getting round the negotiating table, not planning to disrupt millions."

Labour's Ed Miliband would face huge political pressure to condemn a strike as Unite are his party's biggest donor.

Mr McCluskey said drivers were ready to stop work early next month unless an "amicable settlement" could be reached.

It is feared a strike could spark scenes similar to 2000 when lorry drivers blockaded refineries to hit deliveries in response to rising fuel prices.

Motorists stockpiled petrol before the pumps ran dry, forcing garages to ration fuel.

Medics' walkout 'deadly'

A PATIENT may have died because striking ambulance workers refused to return to work, a report claims.

The tragedy occurred in London three hours after unions ignored ambulance chiefs' requests to get frontline staff back.

An NHS report said: "One patient death has been potentially linked to a delayed response during the industrial action." The London Ambulance Service is investigating.

More than half of the capital's ambulance workers joined the November 30 public-sector strike. About 77 per cent of "immediately life threatening" calls were not reached within the eight-minute target.

Ten took over an hour to answer. Two took over two hours.

pages.subdeck: Warned by watchdog ... Theresa May
pages.headline: Terror laws axe puts Brits at risk
pages.teaser: TOUGH restrictions had been a 'useful and necessary' weapon against extremists but new rules 'aid fanatics'
pages.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
NATIONAL security HAS been put at risk by the Coalition's decision to axe control orders, the official terrorism watchdog warned yesterday.

In a devastating report, David Anderson insisted the tough restrictions had been a "useful and necessary" weapon against violent extremists.

And he warned their replacement  Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures  were not up to the job. There was fury when the weaker TPIMs were brought in by the Coalition last year.

Mr Anderson said the changes "were motivated by civil liberties concerns".

He added: "They are unlikely to further the requirements of national security  rather the reverse."

Mr Anderson stressed that control orders had been an "effective means of protecting the public from a small number of suspected terrorists who presented a substantial risk to national security".

He said: "Control orders prevented persons believed to be terrorists from travelling overseas."

They also stopped them "maintaining contact with senior al-Qaeda personnel, providing funds, facilitating the travel and training of others and engaging in terrorist-related activity within the UK."

One of the key powers ditched in the switch to TPIMs was the power to relocate terror suspects to different parts of the country.

Mr Anderson said: "The police stated the loss of the power 'will significantly increase challenges we face'."

He also said the fact TPIMs only lasted two years will "strengthen the resolve of a terrorist who  confronted with an order of potentially indefinite length  might have proved more willing to compromise".

Last night Labour called on Home Secretary Theresa May to "take heed".

Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: "The report shows six terror suspects previously relocated, with a number kept out of London, are now allowed to return under the new powers even though they are a continued threat."

A Home Office spokesman insisted: "Our first priority is national security. The TPIM regime provides effective powers."

pages.subdeck: Balcony horror ... tragic Harry Harling
pages.headline: Dubai booze session boy's death plunge
pages.teaser: COPS trying to discover how he fell after night out with pals
pages.articlebody:
COPS were last night trying to discover how a British schoolboy plunged 11 floors to his death after drinking in Dubai.

Harry Harling, 15, who lived there with his ex-pat family, had spent the night with pals.

He returned home in the early hours of Saturday  and then mysteriously fell from a balcony on a building site.

The rugby-mad Year 11 pupil  who studied at Jumeirah College in the UAE  said on Twitter before heading out: "Beers and tanning with the lads justwhatIneed."

But his puzzling last tweet read: "F*** the system."

Grieving pal Harry Francis spoke of his guilt after leaving his chum on the night out. He wrote of Facebook: "Mate I'm so sorry, I should of never left you alone on Friday. I should of stayed with you till you got a taxi.

"I hope you can find it in your heart to forgive me." Another friend, James Ozden, replied by saying: "Everyone is thinking of ways they could have changed the outcome but its not fair for you to blame yourself!"

Last night his mum Beverley, 46, dad Nicolus, 49 and 19-year-old sister Rebecca were struggling to come to terms with his death. The family, originally from Woking, Surrey, moved to Dubai nine years ago.

College principal Fiona Cottam said counselling was being offered to shocked pupils and staff.

CID chief Major General Khalil al Mansouri said Harry had just left a party on Friday night where there was "drinking". Police are investigating but he said it was not a criminal inquiry.

It is not known how Harry was able to buy alcohol in Dubai, where the legal drinking age is 21. Strict Muslim laws mean it can be bought only in hotels or bars owned by hotels.

The Foreign Office said: "We are aware of the death of a British minor in Dubai and are providing consular assistance."

pages.subdeck: Drama ... balloon
pages.headline: Hitting pylon was like being in a firework
pages.teaser: MAN in a hot air balloon which blew into power cables in a hail of sparks describes horror
pages.articlebody:
A PASSENGER in a hot air balloon which blew into power cables in a hail of sparks said last night: "It was like being in a firework."

Colin Jiggle, a female passenger and teenage pilot Adam Griffiths were hanging 45ft above ground for FIVE HOURS before they could be rescued.

Yesterday Colin, 52, said: "We'd had a very serene flight. I have a pilot's licence but never been in a balloon before. When we went into the lines and the pylon there was a lot of sparks. They burnt my jacket. It was like being in a firework."

The balloon struck the 132,000-volt cables in a field in Bozeat, Northants, just after 6pm on Sunday.

Pilot Adam Griffiths, 18, suffered minor burns. He said: "There was quite a bang and a little bit of a fire in the basket, but it put itself out as I went to grab the fire extinguisher. We slid down the power line and came to a standstill."

They were rescued after the electricity was turned off. It will be switched on when the balloon is finally untangled.

The accident has been put down to freak winds.

pages.articlebody:
UP to 50,000 foreign students went missing because of a major UK Border Agency blunder, it is revealed today.

The National Audit Office said the immigrants were given student visas in 2009 and 2010, but may not have attended college.

An NAO report said the UKBA switched to a new system "before key controls were in place".

It claimed staff "did not check" if those granted visas became students. NAO chief Amyas Morse said: "The flaws were predictable and avoidable."

Nearly 300,000 foreign students and their families are given visas every year.

Labour introduced supposedly harsher restrictions in 2009, with foreign students having to be sponsored by colleges and banned from moving between institutions.

But between February 2010 and October 2011, 62,000 foreign students were still reported for not attending classes.

An NAO contractor took just a week to track down around 200 "lost" people.

The NAO also claimed the Border Agency did "little" to kick out students whose requests for extensions are refused. Just 2,900 have been deported since 2009.

Immigration Minister Damian Green said the Coalition is "stamping out abuse" of the system.

pages.subdeck: Skin kin ... some of the 16 albino members of the Parvez family from Coventry who are set to be Guinness World Record holders
pages.headline: The fairest of them all
pages.teaser: 16-STRONG Asian family from the West Midlands are all white-skinned with fair hair
pages.articlebody:
THE world's biggest albino family is living in the UK, it was revealed last night.

White-skinned couple Aslam Parvez, 55, and wife Shameem, 56, are the eldest of the 16-strong clan from Coventry.

The Asian family, who live within five miles of one another, are all are white-skinned with white hair.

They have difficulty seeing in strong light and are unable to sit in bright sunshine for more than ten minutes because their skin burns so easily.

All of the couple's six children  daughters Naseem, 33, Mukadas, 27, and Musarat, 20, and sons Ghulam, 31, Haider Ali, 29, and Mohammed, 18  have inherited the genetic condition.

Two of Aslam's brothers and a sister have the condition too.

His three siblings have five albino children between them  making them the biggest albino family in the world.

Revealing a fascinating insight into their lives, eldest son Ghulam told how, despite difficulties as they grew up, they have never let their albinism get them down.

He said: "Growing up was hard for all of us. No one wants to look so different and with our pale skins and white hair we really stood out.

"Of course, we were teased when we went out of the house. And even now if we all go out together our unusual looks make people stop and stare.

"But people in the local area are used to us and we have always been accepted by the Muslim community.

"Perhaps having this condition has made us particularly close as a family. But thankfully, as there's so many of us, we've never felt lonely."

This month The Sun revealed that the largest albino family was thought to be the ten-strong Pullan family, from Delhi, India.

But now Guinness World Records have told the Parvez family they would be verifying that they had the record.

Incredibly, until Aslam, a retired mechanic, was born in the Fifties no one had any idea the condition existed in the family.

Ghulam said: "My dad's parents, both originally from Pakistan, were normal brown-skinned Muslims.

"In fact, their first two children  both girls  were absolutely fine.

"Then my dad was born with the condition and out of nine brothers and sisters, three others were also born as albinos.

"Then no one really understood why his parents had so many albino children.

"But with genetic research we now know that, although they both looked normal, both my grandad and his wife carried the albino gene."

When Aslam was 11 his family moved from Pakistan to the UK.

Then the time came for him to get married and he and his brother, who both had arranged marriages, were matched with Shameem and her sister.

They came from a different family but also both had albinism.

Ghulam said: "My mum and dad felt so lucky to find one another.

"Mum has said she did worry when she was young that because she was albino she wouldn't be able to marry.

"So she was thrilled when her parents said they'd managed to match not only her but her sister as well with two brothers who were also albino.

"As they all had the same pale skin and white hair, it seemed obvious that they fitted together as a match.

"It truly seemed a miracle  and when they met it was like looking at a mirror image of one another.

"It definitely helped because both of them understood what it was like to be albino and it meant they weren't alone.

"Back then, no one understood the genetics or that if an albino married an albino, they would definitely have albino children.

"Now we understand more and knew that if we married someone with normal brown skin then our children would not be albino."

As a family they all have the eyesight problems which are common in albinos.

Ghulam  who is an IT expert but unemployed at the moment  added: "We are always squinting in the daylight and our eyesight is very poor.

"It's difficult to see more than a few metres ahead, yet wearing contact lenses makes the light glare even worse.

"In the summer we can wear sunglasses. Otherwise, many of us wear hats to keep the light from hurting our eyes."

Ghulam, who is married to Najma, 33, who has normal brown skin, also told how some people do not believe he is the biological dad to his daughter Sidra Begum, ten, and son Ahmed, eight.

Because his wife does not carry the albino gene, his son and daughter were born with the same colour skin as hers.

Ghulam said: "When my son was a baby I often got strange looks from passers-by because I was this white man with a brown-skinned baby.

"Even now at school my son says children sometimes ask him why he has such a white dad.

"It's quite hard to explain why, so I just tell him to say I am special and he seems happy with that.

"Apart from our skin colour, we do look the same. You can tell we are related. We have the same facial characteristics and ears."

Unusually, his nephew Asad has a white streak in his hair, the only sign of albinism in him.

Ghulam explained: "My sister was amazed when her son was born with a white streak.

"When he was a newborn baby he had a white patch on his head and everyone thought it was a birthmark.

"Then the hair there began to grow white and he now has a white streak in his dark hair.

"No one can understand how that has happened."

The family are definitely special, though.

Ghulam added: "We are quite sure we are unique in the UK. And although we've read about other albino families abroad, we haven't even heard of any family with so many with the same condition."

Until the Pullan and Parvez families turned up, the world record was shared by two families.

Both six-strong, one lives in the US and the other in Canada.

But the Parvez family are on track to take the world record now.

Albino facts



Albinism affects around one in 17,000 people from all ethnic backgrounds.

For a baby to be born albino, both parents must carry the albino gene.

If both parents do carry the gene, there is a one in four chance that their baby will inherit the condition.

Children born to parents who do not have the condition are often carriers.

The term albinism is derived from the Latin word albus, meaning white.

myView



By PROFESSOR ANDREW READ, Geneticist

ALBINOS are people who cannot produce melanin, the dark pigment that colours our skin, hair and eyes.

The problem is genetic. Curiously, it also affects the way the eyes are wired up to the brain, so albinos also have vision problems.

We all have two copies of that gene, one inherited from each of our parents.

If even one copy works, you can make melanin and look normal.

But if two people marry, each with one defective copy, there is a one in four chance that a child would inherit both non-working genes and be born albino.

Albinism affects both sexes  and all races.

It's especially striking when it affects normally dark-skinned African people.

Albinism is only one of several different genetic conditions that can affect pigmentation.

But the pink eyes and poor vision make it special.

pages.subdeck: 6% pay rise ... but Mini workers will have 10mins less for breaks per day
pages.headline: We'll boost pay if you cut tea breaks
pages.teaser: CAR giant is handing British employees a bumper pay rise  as long as they cut breaks
pages.articlebody:
CAR giant BMW is handing British workers a bumper pay rise  as long as they cut their TEA BREAKS.

The German firm  famed for its success with the Mini  wants production line staff to spend less time supping brews.

Bosses will offer a pay rise of six per cent to 1,800 workers at the plant in Cowley, Oxford, tomorrow.

But a third of it will be conditional on the plant meeting end-of-year targets.

And BMW yesterday confirmed staff would be asked to cut their tea breaks by at least ten minutes to just 43 minutes per day. Furious trade union members said the workforce would be up in arms. One told Sun City: "After what they've done to shift patterns recently we feared the pay deal would come with strings attached.

"We get 26 minutes in the morning and 27 in the afternoon for a break. And when you're on the line you need time for a tea or coffee.

"They should use some of the money they've been wasting. When the German managers came over and said the place was a bit messy they went and planted a load of trees to pretty it up." The pay deal is more than THREE TIMES higher than the average UK wage settlement.

But car workers have been getting as much as seven per cent as the motor trade begins to boom.

Britain's automotive sector has been the one shining light of the recovery  with January exports to non-EU countries hitting an all-time high. Cowley makes 200,000 Minis a year.

BMW last night insisted its offer was "strong".

A spokeswoman said: "The company has been looking at a range of options around how we manage our production breaks from 2013 onwards.

"The plant will continue to operate a system of paid breaks for its production employees. No agreement has been reached on this matter and the options are still open to negotiation."



Comet's got twist in its tale

COMET has recorded its best sales for TWO YEARS  months after being flogged for £2.

Chairman John Clare said the turnaround at the electricals specialist was going "as well as we'd have hoped".

Takings in February were ahead of the same month last year. And Comet hopes to break even for 2012.

Mr Clare, appointed after the takeover by private equity group OpCapita, told Sun City: "Last month we beat our own forecasts.

"It was the best sales month for at least a couple of years. But we are trying to come out of a bloody big hole."

Mr Clare said the chain was benefiting from a "more focused" approach to products and advertising.

Up to 2,000 staff have been put on notice to try to slash costs.

But Mr Clare denied he was planning to put a third of Comet's stores up for sale as part of the cost-cutting.

He said: "It will give me a lot of satisfaction when we come out of the other end of the tunnel. I think Comet can be turned around."



Coutts booted

THE Queen's bankers COUTTS was yesterday handed a huge fine for leaving itself open to high-risk money launderers.

The bank  part of RBS  was hit for £8.75million by regulators for "serious and systemic" failings.

The Financial Services Authority said Coutts did not have proper checks and was at "unacceptable risk" of handling stolen cash between 2007 and 2010.

RBS or its subsidiaries have been fined £25million in little more than 18 months. RBS Wealth chief Rory Tapner said Coutts had made improvements.



EDF's oldie aid

THE most complained about energy supplier in Britain has vowed to hand its cheapest deal to its most vulnerable customers.

EDF ENERGY yesterday said around 150,000 hard-up pensioners would automatically get its "best price" from April.

Each one will get a rebate equal to the difference between EDF's cheapest gas and electricity deal and the tariff they are on.

EDF separately claimed it would tell customers when they can save more than £1 per week switching to a RIVAL.

But they first have to sign up to the new "Blue Price Promise" package.

Jim Poole, of EDF, said: "We want to do things other suppliers are not doing."



Oil's well in Africa

BRITAIN'S TULLOW OIL has made the first oil discovery in KENYA.

The find cements East Africa as a new oil and gas frontier.

Tullow called the success at its Ngamia field an "excellent start" to its campaign, which is also targeting Ethiopia.

Shares leapt seven per cent to 1570p. Jubilant Kenyan energy minister Kiraitu Murungi hailed the find by waving a bottle of crude, saying: "It's the beginning of a long journey to make us an oil producer."

pages.byline: By EMILY NASH and GARY O'SHEA
pages.articlebody:
THE former boyfriend of Tulisa Contostavlos broke his silence over their infamous sex tape yesterday and insisted it was HER idea.

Rapper MC Ultra  real name Justin Edwards  denied releasing the explicit footage, which shows the X Factor judge in an intimate moment with him.

He also backed a legal ban on the clip and said it should never have been made public.

In a statement read to London's High Court, Edwards, 28, said: "I am disgusted it has been, and regret ever allowing the claimant to persuade me that we should film ourselves."

He maintained he would not have published the clip  adding: "Simply because I would find it ungentlemanly. I was brought up better than that."

After the hearing, Edwards exclusively told The Sun: "I'm just relieved to have a chance to tell my side of the story.

"It can't happen soon enough. I've had to move out of my home and it's been a nightmare for my family.

"I just want this sorted out so I can move on with my life."

Last Friday Edwards was slapped with a £100,000 claim for damages for alleged breach of privacy and confidentiality by Tulisa, who accused him of leaking the six-minute video.

But yesterday he suggested the footage  published online last week  was filmed on the N-Dubz star's phone and denied he'd ever owned it.

His statement read: "I simply do not, and never have, possessed the film referred to."

Yet Tulisa's QC Desmond Browne told Mr Justice Tugendhat the singer had been "the victim of a vindictive act of betrayal by Mr Edwards  seemingly motivated by personal spite and financial greed".

He called the rapper's denial that he passed on the sex tape "hypocrisy" and "a deceitful representation of the position".

Tulisa, 23, won an injunction last week after the video appeared on the net for downloads.

In a preliminary hearing yesterday Mr Justice Tugendhat extended the ban on anyone using, publishing, communicating or disclosing the clip to any other person.

A date for the next hearing has not yet been set.

pages.articlebody:
DANCING On Ice champion Matthew Wolfenden is marking his victory  with a visit to hospital for TWO MRI scans.

The Emmerdale star beat Jorgie Porter and Chico Slimani in Sunday night's final but the gruelling competition has left him suffering a catalogue of injuries.

Between rehearsals with his ice partner Nina Ulanova, Matthew kept up working five days a week playing David Metcalfe in the ITV soap.

He told TV Biz: "I've bust both my tendons in my ankles. I've had my feet in a bucket of ice every day for weeks to take the pain down.

"I can't lift my right arm properly so I'm going for an MRI scan on Tuesday. I think it's to do with my rotator cuff.

"Then when I have the MRI scan on my shoulder, I need to have one on my knee too because when I dropped Nina out of the headbanger in training, I landed on my knee and I've ripped all the bits in the back of it.

"My back and wrist hurts from the lifts and I've done my groin in.

"I've got a week off the ice to let everything relax, then the tour starts. But I've no time off work."

Matthew trained to be a gymnast from the age of four but had to quit the British team after breaking his back in a fall from the rings aged 17. Due to the stress of training, his old spinal injury flared up again.

He said: "It's definitely affected me on Dancing On Ice. I've had back problems since week two when I trapped a nerve."

Partner Nina added: "He'll never admit it but he is in a lot of pain." The injury to his shoulder is so bad that Matthew thinks he would have LOST if the competition had gone on for another week.

On Sunday night's show the judges could see him struggling to get Nina above his head and Matthew said: "Midway through the competition those lifts were popping up dead easily and yesterday it was really hard.

"I don't think I'd have coped with the lifts if we'd had one more week to go. If the final had been next week then I think we'd have had to take all the lifts out."

Nina also got a share of injuries throughout the series. Not only did Matthew repeatedly drop her as he practised his lifts, he also slashed her leg open with the toe picks on his boots, leaving her with a huge scar.

He said: "We put in blood, sweat and tears  lots of blood."

Matthew and Hollyoaks star Jorgie had to pull off three routines in the final  a showcase dance, their favourite routine from the series and their version of Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean's Bolero dance. Show judges and Olympians Katarina Witt and Robin Cousins said Matthew could have been an international ice skating champ if he had started at a young age.

Now he is hoping to get his toddler son Buster  whose mum is Matthew's co-star fiancée Charley Webb  to try ice skating.

Matthew said: "Our northern coach, Stephen Pickavance, told me, 'You should have done this as a kid, you'd have gone so far.'

"I'm definitely going to get Buster on the ice now this has all finished because it's brilliant and he'll love it.

"Now I can whizz him around and I feel confident enough. It will be great."

Matthew thought he would never win a sporting trophy again after his gymnastic career was over, but winning Dancing On Ice is a great consolation prize.

He said: "It was amazing to win in an Olympic year. This makes up for the gymnastics a little bit. Training was my life until I had my accident and broke my back."

Matthew has been a huge hit with fans on Dancing On Ice but he insists he will never quit his soap role.

He said: "I don't want to leave Emmerdale. It's my bread and butter and they've been so accommodating throughout this whole show.

"Everyone at Emmerdale is just brilliant. I've signed a contract that takes me to Christmas then, hopefully, I'll get a new one after that too."

Matthew revealed he has a huge storyline coming up  and hinted that David's ex-girlfriend Leyla Harding (Rokhsaneh Ghawam-Shahidi) could be returning to cause trouble for him.

He said: "I've got a big new storyline. It's to do with Alicia and David and the little one, Jacob.

"Maybe Leyla might mess things up and come back  but I can't tell you if she will or not!"

pages.subdeck: On road to recovery ... Robin Gibb composed The Titanic Requiem while undergoing chemo
pages.headline: Robin Gibb: Writing Titanic music helped me to battle cancer
pages.teaser: HOW working on symphony marking 100 years since Titanic disaster helped Bee Gee
pages.articlebody:
IT is a maritime disaster that has always fascinated.

April 15 marks 100 years since the "unsinkable" liner RMS Titanic hit an iceberg on its maiden voyage and sank, claiming 1,517 lives.

In a series ahead of the anniversary, this week we explore stories of the Titanic.

Here pop legend Robin Gibb reveals the extraordinary personal circumstances which led to his interest in the tragedy and how it shaped his music.

HE has had a hand in writing some of pop music's most memorable hits, and has sold more than 200million records worldwide.

But it was writing a symphony about the sinking of the Titanic which helped pull Robin Gibb through a personal tragedy.

The Bee Gee has had a lifelong fascination with the ship, and to mark the 100th anniversary of the disaster he has composed his first classical work The Titanic Requiem, with son RJ, 29.

Robin says concentrating his energies on the piece helped him battle liver cancer.

He was diagnosed with the disease last year and is now recovering.

In an exclusive interview with The Sun, Robin, 62, said: "I'm truly grateful that working on The Titanic Requiem distracted me from my illness to such a degree that I truly believe it might have saved my life."

Robin's fascination with the Titanic story stems from boyhood, when he was caught up in a violent storm at sea.

He said: "One of my earliest memories goes back to when I was a little boy of seven and my grandmother told me how her mother cried floods of tears when she heard that the Titanic had sunk.

"Then, when I was eight and me and my family were sailing to Australia to start our musical career and begin a new life, we got caught in a monsoon.

"At times the waves flung the boat high, the next minute deep in a trough. The passengers were collapsing all over the deck and being sick but I wasn't.

"Then the captain made the announcement, 'Do not worry. There hasn't been a tragedy at sea since the Titanic went down in 1912'.

"It wasn't true, of course, or heartening for us passengers. But yet again, the spectre of the Titanic had been raised."

Robin, his brothers and their parents were almost killed at sea themselves when, in 1967 on the way back from Australia, their ship travelled through the Suez Canal.

He recalls: "A civil war was going on in Aden and our boat was fired upon. We were all ordered off the deck and into our cabins. It was quite exciting at the time but we could have all been killed."

That same year Robin narrowly missed losing his life again, when he and his then wife-to-be, Molly, were involved in the Hither Green rail disaster, in south London, in which 49 people died. He says: "I felt on top of the world that morning as the Bee Gees had just had a big hit with Massachusetts. Looking back, Massachusetts probably saved my life.

"Until that record hit the Top Ten I would never have been able to afford a First Class train ticket. But on that occasion, because Massachusetts was doing so well, I did.

"And like everyone else travelling First Class that day, both Molly and I had more chance of surviving the crash than those who weren't.

"But though we did survive, I saw harrowing things I've never forgotten.

"Headless bodies being dragged out of the train wreck, people screaming.

"Molly and I were rushed to hospital in Lewisham so we could be examined for injuries. I had broken glass from the train windows tangled in my hair.

"It took days to remove it but that was really the least of it. The shock and the horror was far, far worse. When we got to the hospital it looked like a war zone. All around us people were being carried in on stretchers and some of their injuries were horrific. Suddenly, it all became too much for me.

"The worst thing of all was that I was unable to help anyone, to mitigate their suffering, I couldn't cope with that.

"I knew I had to get away from all the carnage so I checked out of the hospital and instead went to stay with the Bee Gees' manager, Robert Stigwood.

"After that I suffered a delayed reaction. For days and days I couldn't stop crying. In the end the only thing which saved me was my music, composing with my brothers and singing again.

"But although I did recover, I'll never really forget the horror of the Hither Green train crash and the tragedy of all those poor souls who died or were injured in it."

Robin makes it clear that he does not think living through the rail disaster qualifies him for understanding the Titanic tragedy more than others. However, he believes it is easier for him to walk in the shoes of the doomed Titanic passengers.

As an avid collector of Titanic memorabilia, he has always been obsessed by the tragedy.

His collection includes a pen fashioned from pieces of the wreckage.

It was a present from second wife Dwina, who also gave one to RJ.

And that led him to change tack from composing pop music and, with RJ  also a talented musician  embark on composing his first classical work.

Robin adds: "It has taken us two years to complete The Titanic Requiem.

"Two years of dedication, and I'm definitely very proud of it."

RJ is also proud of the composition, and equally proud of his father's courage in working day and night on it while undergoing chemotherapy to combat his cancer.

RJ says: "He kept going on against all odds. He has been every inch a professional and he deserves a medal for it. For him to come straight out of chemotherapy and into the studio is incredible.

"We've always been close but working on a piece of music that is meant to last for hundreds of years brought us even closer.

"We composed the requiem in order to honour the memory of those who died and to celebrate the age in which they lived."

Robin adds: "I never pushed RJ to become a musician, though. I wanted him to excel at whatever he wanted to do but I never pressured him.

"As he grew older it turned out that he had a flare for melody, and like me and my brothers, who never had music lessons, he flourished. Our collaboration has been wonderful. We have already started working on our next joint classical composition, The First World War Requiem.

"But neither of us will be giving up pop music, either. RJ will be recording an album, Instant Love, and I will be working with Barry again, I'm looking forward to it.

"I just hope that The Titanic Requiem will be a fitting memorial for all those brave souls who died during the tragedy, so they will never be forgotten."

One of the most moving elements in the requiem is the song Don't Cry Alone, which Robin sings. It tells of a man who knows he is going to die begging his wife not to cry alone when he's gone.

It is a song that Dwina finds particularly emotional.

She says: "When Robin first played me the song he was in the middle of chemotherapy. I cried when I heard it. It brought up all my fears that I might lose him."

Robin jokes: "I was afraid that I might lose me, too. Luckily, I was wrong... "

  • The Titanic Requiem is released as an album tomorrow and will be performed in concert at Central Hall in London's Westminster on April 11. Tickets are available now. See robingibb.com.

pages.subdeck: 'My photo journey reminds me how hard I worked' ... Nicola Williams
pages.headline: 11st weightloss picture diary
pages.teaser: TEACHER shares snaps she took every month until she reached her goal...a size 12
pages.articlebody:
WHEN primary school teacher Nicola Williams decided to lose weight, she looked to herself for inspiration.

She decided to take a self-portrait every month to clearly see her progress and motivate her to continue.

Her inspiring photo casebook charts her epic FOUR-YEAR weight loss  from 24 stone and a size 32 to the 13 stone size 12 she is today.

Her incredible photo diary helped her jack in the junk food and bin the bad habits in pursuit of a healthier, happier life.

Now, looking back through the pictures proves incredibly emotional for Nicola, 39.

She says: "When I show people they stare open-mouthed as I flick through the album and shrink before their eyes.

I can't believe how big I was and how much I've transformed. It's incredible and I love the new improved me.

"My photo journey reminds me of how hard I worked to get where I am today and I hope it inspires other women to begin their own journey."

At the age of 24, Nicola was 16 stone and by the time she was 34 she weighed 24st.

She recalls: "I worried if I was going to fit through a small gap or get stuck on a small chair. So I'd try to avoid putting myself in potentially embarrassing situations.

"For breakfast, I'd have four slices of toast. For lunch I'd make a sandwich with four slices of white bread with double the filling.

"Dinners were always whatever was quick. Pasta bakes, pizzas and takeaways were my regular meals of choice.

"My biggest weakness though, were crisps. I'd never go a day without eating at least three bags.

"Working as a primary school teacher, the staff room is always full of cakes and chocolates to snack on during break times."

Nicola, of Llanelli, Wales, was eating around 4,900 calories a day, 2,900 above the recommended intake. And it affected her confidence.

She says: "Trying to run around with the kids during PE lessons and teaching them about healthy lifestyles was always difficult as I felt like a hypocrite."

She also struggled to find clothes to flatter her huge frame. She continues: "I had to settle for T-shirts that managed to cover my enormous body and trousers that didn't dig in to my sides.

"The only things that looked good were shoes. I loved being able to walk into High Street shops and pick out a pair of pretty high heels, slip them on my feet and feel sexy.

"So I went crazy for them. Platforms, stilettos, boots, wedges  you name them, I had a pair. In every colour and for every occasion I had shoes that made me feel great.

"Worth more than £3,500, I had just over 100 pairs in my collection before my life changed."

Then, in December 2007, Nicola joined a weekly slimming class  purely to keep a friend company.

She says: "I swapped white bread for brown, reduced my portion sizes and snacked on fruit and veg. I found it surprisingly refreshing to come out of my normal convenience eating routine and try something new."

Within a month, Nicola had shed 10lb. Yet she struggled to see a difference in her appearance.

"So my friend suggested taking a picture to show me how well I'd done. It was the motivation I needed to carry on," she says.

"Comparing myself month by month stunned me. My face was thinner and I could notice the difference in my waistline and arms.

"I began looking forward to each month when the time came to take a picture and compare myself to the previous one."

Nicola also joined a gym and began working out twice a week.

She says: "After the first year I'd lost five stone  down from 24st to 19st.

"My meals changed completely to consist of a piece of toast for breakfast, a sandwich with two pieces of brown bread for lunch, fruit for a snack and meat with vegetables for dinner.

"Looking at myself filled me with pride and the compliments I was receiving from friends and family were incredible.

"I was determined this wasn't going to just be a fad diet phase  this was a new lifestyle for me."

In the next three years she lost a further six stone, dropping to 13st 2lb.

Nicola says: "Every woman wants to look their best in a photo.

"If I was ever tempted to have a take-away binge at the end of the month, I'd think about having my picture taken and it would put me off."

And for shoe-mad Nicola there was only one way to mark her sensational new figure.

"In January this year I splashed out on a beautiful pair of £380 cream Jimmy Choo shoes to celebrate."

MADONNA has never been what you would call a modest dresser.

But at a Miami gig at the weekend these cheeky hotpants set tongues wagging.

At 53, is it time to hang up the risque costumes?

Here is the view of one controversial writer.

OVER the past three decades I have made more bitchy comments about Madonna than Elton John has.

I still maintain that if ordinary citizens went about showing their sex organs to all and sundry, they'd be locked up, not handsomely rewarded.

But, albeit belatedly, I feel I must come to Madge's defence. Of course popular music is, ideally, a young person's racket.

If all pop stars of both sexes retired from the stage when they were young and fresh, fine.

Take TV. Where's the logic in letting men go on until they look like resentful Galapagos tortoises while women are shoved off screen as soon as they can hold a pencil under their breasts?

Women are more than half the population and their eye candy requirements should be catered to.

No one says that George Michael, Madonna's contemporary, should throw in the men-only sauna towel.

Another of her generation, Michael Jackson, was indulged when it came to the ageing process, still playing the Peter Pan card when he frankly looked more like Baby Jane.

Mick Jagger is a decade and a half older than Madonna, yet is still the shrivelled subject of such ludicrous tributes as Moves Like Jagger.

The writer Truman Capote called him "about as sexy as a p***ing toad"  and now he looks as if a bored giant practised origami on his face for a very long time before throwing the mangled plaything aside.

When Clive Dunn crooned Grandad on Top Of The Pops in the Seventies, he spent hours in make-up to look the part.

But Jagger, McCartney, Tom Jones  the prancing grandads are for real now. So why the vapours over Madonna in her shorts when she still has the body of a woman half her age?

If women are past it at 50, think about men and the way their bodies specifically become unappetising. Most of them are more Wayne Rooney than George Clooney to start with and time is rarely kind.

What's sauce for the goose is good for the gander  and next to a pair of knee-length, wizened testicles (yes, I KNOW we can't see them, but we all KNOW they're there) what's a bit of turkey neck?

Go, Madge! Just keep your pants on this time...

Jessie J

Style: The singer's trademark jewellery reveals a powerful personality who is happy to show she is on top.

Style secret: Lots of flash or expensive gear can mask a deeper insecurity that makes the wearer feel a need to prove themself.

Holly Willoughby

Style: Holly's style is feminine and traditional, but with a twist of sexiness.

Style secret: The girl next door may secretly wish to be more assertive and outgoing. Often more complicated than she appears.

She explained: "I get way too much male attention, but I won't date until the octuplets are 18  I live for them now.

"I know a lot of women like male attention, but I'll go out with no make-up on and wear tracksuits, a wig and even a fake pregnancy stomach to put them off."

She added: "I wouldn't rule out a relationship in the future. But now, when men look at me, I look away and they know not to approach me.

Nadya, who lives in California, US, already had six kids  Elijah, now 10, Amerah, nine, Joshua, eight, Aiden, six, and twins Caleb and Calyssa, five, when she claims she decided to have more embryos implanted from the same sperm donor.

And her brood was soon joined by six boys and two girls  Noah, Jonah, Jeremiah, Isiah, Josiah, McCai, Maliah and Nariah, who turned three in January this year.

But amazingly, the 36-year-old says it was no effort at all to get her figure back following her last pregnancy.

She explained: "I just pinged back into shape like a rubber band after the kids  I don't know how I did it.

"I eat like a horse, don't count calories and have never owned a set of scales.

"I gained an entire human when I was pregnant with the octuplets  going from 10st to over 19st  but, two months later, I was a size eight again. Now, I never weigh myself."

pages.subdeck: Regrets ... Michelle Pfeiffer reveals what she wishes she'd known at 18
pages.headline: What I wish I'd known at 18
pages.teaser: THE Hollywood star now recognises the importance of a good education
pages.articlebody:
MICHELLE PFEIFFER became famous thanks to 1980s films such as The Witches Of Eastwick, Dangerous Liaisons and The Fabulous Baker Boys.

She had established herself as one of the world's best-known actresses by the time she cut back on movies to bring up her family.

She has adopted daughter Claudia Rose, 18, and son John Henry, 17, with second husband, TV producer David E. Kelley.

Michelle, 53, who co-stars with Johnny Depp in upcoming film Dark Shadows, is also known for her work with charities helping cancer patients. Here, she tells GARTH PEARCE what she wished she knew aged 18.

"I WISH I had known at 18 the importance of education.

I was always at the beach. I couldn't wait to get out of school. I was so bored.

I was a California girl to a T, being brought up in Midway City between Los Angeles and San Diego.

I was not a good girl and always in trouble for something or other.

Looking back, I wish I had paid more attention  and I also regret that I did not have teachers who were more interested in me.

When I became a mother, I realised I had not taken enough advantage of my education and came to appreciate how important it really is.

That is completely different to having success.

There are people who have had no education who have made a lot of their lives.

If you are not careful, education can just slip by and it is sometimes hard to get a second chance.

I'd also taken up acting at school because I was so bad at English and thought I would improve by taking theatre studies. But becoming an actress was as unobtainable as going to the moon  or becoming president.

I had worked, part-time, as a check-out girl in a supermarket since the age of 14 and, in the end, I left school at 17 and worked there full-time. I had not learned a thing.

I was living with my parents at home, working the check-out, spending time on the beach and realised I'd better do something with my life. I called a friend of mine, Walter Deadman, who was a hairdresser, who had always been harping on at me to model.

I told him I would like to become an actress.

Instead of laughing, he suggested I join a beauty pageant. I called up a modelling agent, John Robert Powers, who ran a sort of charm school.

I borrowed a dress  I never wore them because they used to call me chicken legs at high school  and went along for some test shots. I used those to put myself up for the pageant.

So I went to LA for the first time in my life for the pageant. The biggest stress was that I smoked and I'd have to give it up for a week! I won a prize, because they suddenly decided they wanted a Miss Orange County. In truth, they had more crowns than people.

But winning that pageant did change my life. I moved out of my parents' house to about half a mile down the road and about six months later signed with an agent.

I got a TV series and did not have to work at the supermarket any more. After that, what happened to me felt very dreamlike  a Disneyland experience, which changed me.

But I also wish I'd have known how being recognised would bother me far more than it should.

I found it disturbing and completely unnatural. There is nothing to prepare you.

I wish I could have handled it better, initially.

I have learned since that it is possible to have both a home life and a working life. The worst moment was when there was a radio report, in the late 1990s, that David had left me for Ally McBeal actress Calista Flockhart  and we were both listening in the car, with the kids!

They gave an on-air apology the next day and I have never heard a more grovelling retraction. But it is hard dealing with that kind of stuff.

I also struggled with my own image as a sexual person.

That ended with a film, The Fabulous Baker Boys in 1989, by which time I was 31.

Even two years before that, I would not have been able to play the part of the sexually appealing Susie Diamond. She was dynamic and unapologetic and I was able to put on those clothes and play the part. I think, because of the way I looked, I had stayed away from buying anything sexy or overtly sexual.

It was a turning point for me, because I could understand why men would find her sexy.

I wish I'd been more like her. Before that, I would walk around looking like a bag lady!

But the biggest turning point in my life was becoming a mother. If you had told me when I was 18 that I could survive on three hours' sleep a night, I'd have never believed it. You just cope.

I would not choose a showbusiness career for my children.

I would say: 'Be a doctor, or something else'. The value of a good education has never left me."

pages.headline: I was too 'fat' to be heroine
pages.teaser: JENNIFER Lawrence had to dye her hair brown and train 3 times a day to prepare for film
pages.articlebody:
IT'S the movie everyone's talking about  and could even put vampire hit Twilight in the shade.

The Hunger Games, which has just opened in the UK, took a whopping $155million (£98million) at the US box office on its opening weekend.

That was the third biggest total ever after Harry Potter And The Deathly Hallows Part 2 and The Dark Knight.

The success of The Hunger Games  a futuristic action movie based on a best-selling trilogy of novels  is set to make star Jennifer Lawrence as big a name as Twilight's Kristen Stewart.

And that is despite fans of the books saying she was "too fat, too pretty and too blonde" to play heroine Katniss Everdeen.

Jennifer, 21, said: "I didn't know until the interviewers told me that all the fans were p****d because I was blonde.

"Then I was like, 'What? Damn, I'll just dye my hair'."

The actress had to endure months of gruelling training to get in shape for the role.

She said: "It was intense. I had training about three times a day for a few months. Then, once we started working, I had to have the training just for endurance because it was so many hours.

"I mean, if there's a scene of me running up a mountain, that's what we shot all day  me running up a mountain.

"I had about six weeks of archery. It was brand new to me and I loved it. I think I'm good at shooting arrows now  and I can skin a squirrel!"

The action was so intense that the star, who is dating British actor Nicholas Hoult, 22, had a constant battle to keep weight on.

She said: "It was great to lose weight because it was unintentional. I didn't go to the gym once. It was just a really physical movie.

"I actually ate more on that movie than I ever have on any other because it was non-stop and physical and I needed energy.

"It happened very naturally with all the training. It was hard to keep weight on for continuity.

"I ate a ton. Any picture you see of me from that set, I'm probably eating."

Jennifer jumped at the chance to play the lead role.

She said: "I loved the books. That was the hardest part for me.

"I almost wished I didn't love them as much as I did because of just the pressure I put on myself to make sure it was something I could be happy about and proud of.

"Katniss is such an iconic character and there is so much pressure just coming from myself because I was a fan."

The movie, based on Suzanne Collins' novels, is set in a future North America destroyed by drought, fire, famine and war.

Each year inhabitants are forced to take part in a televised fight to the death.

Jennifer said: "I think it makes us look at humanity in kind of a real way, where it is is becoming desensitised.

"We can watch the demise of a marriage or we can watch death on television and it's entertainment.

"We're a society that's obsessed with reality. We're obsessed with gossip and bad things happening rather than good stories and good, uplifting things. We live in a world where history repeats itself and it's (the events of the movie) really not that far off, I don't think."

Jennifer is quickly rising up the ranks in Hollywood thanks to the new movie on top of past success. She was nominated for an Oscar last year for her role in thriller Winter's Bone  but she says she does not feel like a star.

She said: "The glamorous part lasts for about five minutes and it doesn't even really feel glamorous. So it just feels like a job. Being on a set is not glamorous.

"I don't really think about it because I don't really like going out that much.

"I'm kind of a home body, so I was stressing out one time about movies and that I won't be able to go out to dinner  I won't be able to go to a bar and just hang out.

"But then I'm always lying to get out of those things anyway. So now I just have an excuse  'I can't go, I'm famous'.

"I guess I feel I have to be more mature. I can't really, like, moon the paparazzi or anything, which is always my dream."

Jennifer, who auditioned for the part of Bella in Twilight, was also in X-Men: First Class last year. But she doesn't want to fall into Hollywood's traps.

She explained: "It is so strange to see in Hollywood how skinny these women are and how that puts pressure on our young girls.

"I remember being in school when I was 14 and girls were on diets and eating salads with dressing on the side. It was just weird.

"It's not healthy because I don't really think that's beautiful. Every time somebody talks about skinny, nobody ever writes how great it is to be skinny and how everyone loves someone who is skinny.

"They're always writing about when this fad is going to end. I can't wait for it to end."

Jennifer plays a former sex addict in forthcoming movie The Silver Linings Playbook, which also stars legend Robert De Niro.

She said: "Fantastic  Robert De Niro. I can't believe I can even talk to him really but he's just so down-to-earth and nice and normal."

And although she is now dating Nicholas she admits there is another British actor she has the hots for  Clive Owen.

After The Hunger Games, most red-blooded men will have the hots for Jennifer too.

Hunger Games facts



THE Hunger Games trilogy of novels has been translated into 26 languages and is on sale in 38 countries.

A whopping ten million copies of the books were sold last year alone.

Writer Suzanne Collins, 50, whose first Hunger Games book came out in 2008, is now Amazon Kindle's best-selling author. She was the first author writing material for young adults to sell more than one million Kindle ebooks.

Catching Fire  the second in the trilogy  was published in 2009 and Mockingjay came out in 2010.

Suzanne said she got the inspiration for the books after surfing channels on her TV. One programme on at the time was a reality TV show and the other was footage of the Iraq War. She said: "The two began to blur in a very unsettling way."

Now the books and the film are so successful that a doll of lead character Katniss is being released.

Thousands of fans have been travelling to North Carolina, where the movie was shot, to do Hunger Games tours. One place featured in the film is Henry River Mill Village. So many fans have turned up there, the local sheriff's department has been forced to call in private security guards to protect the locals.
