pages.headline: 'I need a groom for my wedding'
pages.teaser: STUDENT Rearna has spent months planning her big day even though she's SINGLE
pages.articlebody:
STUDENT Rearna Ackord has been organising her wedding for six months.

The 22-year-old has selected the venue and picked out her £1,100 dream dress.

She has also chosen the song that will play as she walks down the aisle and finalised a menu her guests will be served.

But there is one thing missing from her big day  the groom.

She is one of a growing group of women called the Single Bridezillas, who have planned their weddings down to the last tea light, despite the fact they don't even have a boyfriend.

Rearna, who is reading English Literature at university, said: "Every girl grows up dreaming of their wedding day, fantasising about how they will look and whether their mum will cry.

"I'm just taking it one step further than most and making those dreams a reality."

Rearna was bitten by the bridal bug last year when she visited St Bartholomew's Church near where she studies in Brighton.

She said: "After a string of failed relationships, I used to be the type of girl who couldn't think of anything worse than getting married.

"But when, last year, I went inside that church I had a life-changing moment."

Taking in the beautiful architecture, long aisle and stunning stain glass windows Rearna was "blown away" by the place.

She said: "It was stunning. All of a sudden I could see myself in a gorgeous white dress, walking down the aisle with all my friends and family looking on proudly.

"In that moment I decided I had to get married and started planning straight away. I wanted to put my name on the wedding waiting list there and then."

Within minutes of returning home, Rearna decided both her dad Des, 54, and brother Landon, 19, would walk her down the aisle to the song A Case Of You by James Blake.

She said: "It's such a beautiful song, when I heard it on the radio I instantly said 'That's it'."

Ever since her visit to the church ten months ago, Rearna is "like a woman possessed."

Despite her friends mocking her sudden obsession with her fantasy wedding, Rearna hasn't stopped giving them details of her big day.

She admitted: "My friends laugh at me. They couldn't understand when I first told them I'd started to plan a wedding without a boyfriend.

"Suddenly, bridal shops and wedding magazines became interesting.

"Looking through them for ideas, my mind raced with thoughts of invites, flowers and, of course, the dress."

Rearna was in Uckfield, East Sussex, for a day when she saw an ivory dress on a mannequin in the window of Fross Wedding Collections.

She said: "I stopped in my tracks. I'd seen dresses I liked in the magazines but nothing compared to this.

"I knew straight away it was the dress I was going to get married in and booked an appointment for later that day to try it on.

"My friend Leah Butson  she's a student too  and I both had tears in our eyes as I twirled in front of the mirror with the circular train trailing behind me. It was the stuff of dreams."

Returning home that night, unable to stop thinking about her dream dress, Rearna began to panic that the dress would sell out before she had the funds to buy it.

She said: "I just know how upset I'll be if I finally saved up the money only to find out it's gone. The only way is to put down a deposit of £150, so I'm going to have to save so I can be safe in the knowledge it's mine.

"I go in to try it on at least once a month and because I've been doing it for the past seven months shop owner knows me by name.

"I've even considered taking out a loan to cover the £1,100 to put my mind at rest."

Rearna now visits the church every month to visualise her big day and measure up to work out how many flowers she will need.

She explained: "I sit and picture how it will look. I've planned to have the whole interior lit up with a thousand tea light candles and the pews to be draped with off-white silk. I love animals, so I've asked my best friend if her dogs can be involved. They're going to be dressed in little suits and dresses and will accompany the bridesmaids down the aisle.

"My friend Kirsty Naunton makes amazing cakes so I instantly got her on the phone to discuss what I wanted.

"The chosen cake is three tiers with white icing and diamante-style decorations."

To make sure her dream wedding will not become a distant fantasy, Rearna has made a pact with a close friend, 23-year-old Jonny Gregson, that if neither is married by the age of 30, they'll tie the knot.

She said: "Age 28 is my goal so I have a few years to find someone, finalise my plans and save the £30,000 I need."

Although she's missing a groom, Rearna couldn't wait to break the news to those who make up the rest of the bridal party.

Best friends Olivia Jones, 21, Leah, 22, Kirsty Naunton, 22, and Lil Griffin, 21, will all be bridesmaids.

She said: "Although they think I'm mad, they're all excited.

"I have already taken them to the shop to show them the pink dresses they'll be wearing."

With the ceremony planned in fine detail, Rearna will be taking her guests to the nearby beach for the reception in a giant marquee.

She said: "Living in Brighton, I've decided to have a party on the beach.

"Watching the sun set with my family and friends and new husband will be so amazing."

The single bride-to-be does not want to leave any part unplanned so Rearna has recently finalised her food menu.

She said: "My grandma Daisy Ackord is Jamaican and she makes the best food I've ever tasted, so she's in charge of catering for my big day. I'm going to have a West Indian menu consisting of jerk chicken, specialty rice and peas, ackee and saltfish and special Jamaican cakes for dessert."

Rearna and her gran have worked out the Caribbean feast will cost £50 a head. And for the music, she will hire a jazz-funk band.

She said: "I come from a very musical family and we're all big jazz fans so I've been keeping an eye out for one that can cater for weddings."

Every time someone mentions getting married, Rearna always tries to slip in a mention of St Bartholomew's.

The singleton even spoke to someone who had been married at the venue. When they revealed they had trouble with parking she immediately factored in plans to have minibuses bring guests to the venue.

Despite living on her student loan, Rearna is already trying to save the £30,000 she's worked out she needs for her big day.

She said: "The first thing I'm going to spend my first proper pay cheque on is my wedding dress.

"I'm completely obsessed with it and can't wait to have it hung in my wardrobe instead of in a shop window."

But Rearna is under no illusions  she knows the detail with which she has planned her big day could send a new boyfriend running a mile.

She said: "When I do meet someone I'll be keeping these plans firmly under wraps  until I have a ring on my finger..."

VICTORIA BECKHAM has gone all twirly.

The latest Posh look is a mid-length, softly curled style with what looks to be a few caramel highlights.

The 37-year-old designer tweeted a picture of her discarded hair with the message "Chopped it off!" on a visit to stylist Ken Paves in LA on Friday.

Victoria seems to change hairstyles almost as often as hubby David does.

Sun Fashion Editor TONI JONES rates her "cutting-edge" looks over the years and a body language expert offers her view.

(Left) 1996: A sophisticated, classic bob earns her the Posh nickname when she is in the Spice Girls.

(Right) 1999: A spiky, scary 'do that announces to the world she is ready to move on from the girl group.

(Left) 2000: First foray into faux hair, adding extensions to her cropped locks to look more girly.

(Right) 2001: Her hands-down worse style ever. Fortunately, the skunk-stripe hair is short-lived.

(Left) 2003: WAG-tastic, tumbling hair gives her a glitzy look that screams high maintenance.

(Right) 2004: The extensions are still there, streaked with blonde for a look that's more brassy than classy.

(Left) 2006: Posh creates one of the most copied hairdos of the decade with her dramatic Pob style.

(Right) 2007: Victoria's blonde ambition is obvious as the family up sticks and head to LA.

(Left) 2010: Cheaper than Botox, Croydon facelift shows she means business on American Idol.

(Right) 2012: Simple and very "now", low ponytail is perfect for someone wanting to be taken seriously.

By JUDI JAMES, Body language expert

VICTORIA BECKHAM is very much defined by her hair and style.

She often reverts back to a similar style to the one she had during the height of the Spice Girls and when she fell in love with David.

This is something many women do when they're feeling insecure.

pages.teaser: A GRIEVING mum has blamed toxic PIP breast implants for killing her unborn baby
pages.articlebody:
A GRIEVING mum has blamed toxic PIP breast implants for killing her unborn baby.

Suzanne Ellis believes son Ivan was stillborn after being poisoned by the ruptured implants.

She claimed they leaked industrial-strength silicone  which is used for stuffing mattresses  into her body.

Suzanne said doctors could find no other explanation for the death and is pressing for a probe into the tragedy.

She is also backing The Sun's Safer Surgery campaign for tighter regulations and a Government-backed national register of procedures.

Suzanne, 31, of Widnes, Cheshire, said: "When I decided to have implants, I thought I knew all the risks. I never thought losing my son would be one of them."

She had her breasts enlarged in Manchester in 2007. But after six months one started to swell and she had chest, ear and throat infections.

Suzanne, who has a 14-year-old daughter, then suffered chronic headaches before falling pregnant  when her symptoms got worse. She said: "I'd been pregnant before, but this was horrific."

She developed an intense itching across her body. Suzanne said: "I felt like there was something under my skin. It was awful." Doctors were baffled, but her unborn baby appeared to be OK and Suzanne called him Ivan. But at 27 weeks he was stillborn.

Suzanne said: "I needed answers but nobody could tell me why my perfect baby had died." She and her ex-partner Adam declined a post mortem at the time.

Tests showed a healthy placenta and the cause of death remained a mystery to consultants.

A year after her loss, Suzanne noticed a lump on her breast.

Doctors said her right implant had ruptured  and that it had been made by PIP.

The French company is at the centre of an international health scare over the faulty implants which were given to up to 40,000 British women.

Suzanne, who is waiting to have her implants removed, said: "No wonder I'd been so ill. No wonder my baby died. The manufacturers of PIP implants put my health at risk and risked the life of my son. How many other women have suffered?"

  • SUN doctor CAROL COOPER writes: Nobody knows if PIP implants killed Ivan. There have been no studies into whether they harm babies.

    Any implant is a "foreign body" and could provoke a reaction. Research is still being done. Pregnant women should get advice from their GP.

pages.headline: Honeytrapper could be free in 3yrs
pages.teaser: DISTRAUGHT sister's fury at six-year sentence for 20-year-old honeytrapper Mundill Mahil
pages.articlebody:
STANDING in front of the shrine to her murdered brother, Amandip is distraught and angry  and feels betrayed.

TV boss Gagandip Singh was just 21 when he was lured to his death in a honeytrap  viciously beaten and burned alive in the boot of a Mercedes car.

Amandip, 19, a business studies student, said: "My mother and I are haunted by the way Gagandip was murdered. We saw his horrifically burned body and we cannot get that image out of our minds."

Medical student Mundill Mahil, 20, was jailed last month for six years for GBH with intent. Harvinder Shoker, also 20, got life for murder, while 20-year-old Darren Peters was jailed for 12 years for manslaughter.

Now, Amandip and her mum Tajinder have asked the Attorney General to review the sentence handed to Mahil and set up an e-petition, Justice For Gagandip.

Speaking out for the first time, Amandip added: "He would not have been murdered if Mundill Mahil hadn't lured him to her flat in Brighton in a carefully orchestrated honeytrap.

"Mahil will be released for good behaviour in three years. It's outrageous. Other cases involving money and fraud get much more punishment. Gagandip's life has been taken. I believe something more needs to be done."

Gagandip's body was found in the burning car in Blackheath, south-east London, in February last year.

He had been violently attacked in Brighton before being driven back to the capital and murdered.

A post-mortem examination revealed he was still alive when the fire in the car was started.

It was the second tragedy for the family in just 18 months. In September 2009 Gagandip's father Charanjit was murdered in India. Eight people are on trial there accused of being involved.

Gagandip took over his dad's packaging firm and also started the Sikh TV channel on Sky.

Amandip said: "We were only just starting to come to terms with the first murder when Gagan was killed. It has knocked the life out of me and Mum."

The court heard that Mahil, from Chatham, Kent, had been Gagandip's girlfriend. He was in love but they split up in August 2010 after she alleged he had sexually assaulted her.

Shoker, his friend of five years, also fell in love with Mahil and decided to take revenge on the businessman.

In February last year she lured Gagandip to her house in Brighton.

She knew that Shoker and Peters, both from London, would be lying in wait for him.

He was beaten unconscious and bundled into the boot of the car.

Amandip said: "I only met Mahil once, when Gagandip brought her to our home. She was very pretty and confident and seemed a nice person.

"My brother and I were very close and were both living at home and saw each other every day.

"He became very close to her and said she was a friend he trusted and who he could talk to about anything.

"Look at how she betrayed his trust. She tried to destroy my brother's character in court.

"But he was a kind, generous man who would have done anything to help anyone."

Detective Superintendent Damian Allain, who investigated the case, said after the conviction: "Throughout the investigation and trial Mahil portrayed herself as a victim.

"It is clear to me, now endorsed by the jury's verdict, that her actions were calculating and that she was at the heart of a criminal conspiracy with Shoker and Peters of tricking Gagandip to Brighton to seriously assault him, which resulted in his death."

The family say Gagandip had the world at his feet.

Amandip said: "He ran the family's successful employment agency and packaging business. He also set up and headed Sikh TV.

"In addition, he was the founder of the British Sikh Student Federation. He had made friends and contacts all around the world."

His mother Tajinder, 45, was equally proud of his achievements.

She said: "He had done so much. I didn't think a 21-year-old would be capable of so much.

"I'm amazed how much he achieved. Never a day goes by when we don't think about him.

"I am devastated by my son's killing and struggling to cope. In my life there's only a dead end.

"There's nothing left ahead. The whole story has finished here."

She now runs the family business, which employs 300 people. But with the emotional turmoil of losing her son she found it almost impossible to carry on with it.

She said: "When I first learned of Gagandip's death I was completely and utterly broken.

"I could barely function on a day-to-day basis and stumbled through each day not really knowing what was going on. I do not have the support of a husband because he also died not so long before Gagan.

"I cannot describe on an average day my life since Gagandip's death because they have all blended into one.

"In the early stages I couldn't hold a conversation without breaking down in tears and there were occasions when the police had to call an ambulance for me after I collapsed."

Cherished pictures from the family photo album show what a loving son and brother Gagandip was.

There was also a picture of him at his 21st birthday party with killer Shoker.

Amandip said: "Shoker turned up uninvited to the party.

"We knew things weren't right between Gagandip and Shoker by that stage. The photo of them together is so ironic as they look like the best of friends  and for over five years they were.

"I'm sickened by the thought that the man who holds his hand lovingly over my brother's heart in the photo is the same person who later beat him so terribly then burned him alive.

"He spent so much time around at our house that he practically lived here.

"What he did is such a terrible betrayal of trust."

Gagandip was cremated and his ashes scattered in a river at the Kiratpur Sahib temple in the Punjab, India.

Like her mother, Amandip broke down when she remembered the precious times they had together.

She said: "I found it hard to go into his bedroom without getting very upset."

Now, though, they remember him with the shrine in the garden and in his former bedroom in south east London.

Amandip said: "Mum and I actually slept in his room as a way of trying to feel closer to him.

"Now we have turned his bedroom into a shrine, with a large photo of him on the bed and all his clothes and possessions are still in the room."

Gagandip's mum and sister are still clearly in pain over his loss  but their grief would be easier to bear if they felt justice had been done.

Additional reporting: MARK CHRISTY

pages.headline: War widow predicted death
pages.teaser: WIDOW reveals spooky premonitions in book about her husband Sgt Olaf Schmid
pages.articlebody:
WAR widow Christina Schmid read her hero husband's Tarot cards before his fateful tour  with nightmare results.

The burning Tower card, seen as the harbinger of doom, repeatedly cropped up.

It was one of a host of spooky premonitions she had both before and during hubby Oz's fatal five-month mission to the Afghanistan front line, where he defused 70 Taliban bombs.

Today Christina tells of the dreadful day he begged her to read his future  and the moment she saw his destruction in the cards.

In her own words, taken from her memoir about Staff Sergeant Olaf "Oz" Schmid, Always By My Side, she writes: "Oz asked me to do his Tarot cards.

"The Tarot was something I did very rarely, perhaps once every other year. I wasn't sure about doing it this time, but Oz urged me to and I agreed.

"I had done them since I was young and I seemed to be gifted. The card he chose to show the future was the Burning Tower. I did them again, this time for career, Oz chose the Burning Tower again. The worst card there is.

"It signifies death and endings, the worst outcome imaginable and entirely unavoidable. Everything you know gone in ruin or catastrophe.

Oz looked stricken. He said, 'I feel this is going to be a really bad year for me. I've got this feeling as if everything is slipping'.

"I tried to lighten it, saying, 'You'll probably just stub your toe when you're at work  you're always a screamer with loads of bad luck! Don't worry, it might just mean that you won't get a promotion or something'.

"'No', he said. 'It's not the card. That just confirmed what I already know and feel'.

"When it was my turn to choose a card I hoped I might get something that would lift the mood, but I was startled when I got it in my spread of cards, too.

"But then I got rebirth after, and the moon. 'See, hun  always light in the dark. Remember that', he said. I tried to hide my dismay. 'It's a dark time of year. Perhaps we're both just feeling it', I said.

" 'Let's be positive, forget the cards, we've got lots to look forward to', I chirped, waiting for him to follow my lead.

"He usually did, but this time Oz said, 'No, it's bad. I've got this feeling that if I go out after January or February, I'm not coming back. That's what my gut is telling me'. There was nothing I could say that would cheer him and the truth was it was hard even to try, because I felt worried too."

Despite the omen, devoted Christina put aside her foreboding when Oz was sent to the front.

During his dangerous deployment she would make a wish for his protection during the full moon.

But on the last full moon before Oz's return she inexplicably fell asleep with young son Laird and missed her routine.

She writes: "I woke around 4am, disorientated. I was fully clothed and Laird was asleep on me, in his pyjamas. As the realisation dawned that I had missed doing the wish for Oz, the moon had disappeared and I felt distraught.

" 'Oh my God, what have I done?' I whispered. 'I've done it every month. Why now?'

"I told myself it didn't matter, that it was just a bit of silly tradition, that I should forget it. But I couldn't."

Christina's foreboding grew to fever pitch shortly before Oz, who won a gallantry gong on his tour, was due home.

The spooky signs grew to the point where she says she KNEW he was dead even before the fateful news came with a knock on the door from two officers bringing confirmation.

She writes: "Two days before he was due to leave Afghanistan for home, Oz called again. I could hear immediately that he was low.

"He had been out of contact for several days and he sounded shattered. He said, 'Honey, I just feel really bad, I've got this odd feeling, like dread, I don't feel safe, it's bad. Have you got it too?' I had. In the pit of my stomach I felt a lurch as he spoke.

"I had been uneasy, anxious, and had a feeling of dread, but I didn't want to say that.

'You're tired,' I said. 'It's OK, you'll be back soon. Do what you did the last few months in the next couple of days, hun. You've got 48 hours left, that's all'.

" 'Honey', he said, 'I'm mentally and spiritually hammered, I'm hanging out. I've been away too long, worked too much.

" 'And if it's too much for me it's too much for anyone. But I can't let it show. I've got to keep positive and strong, they (the other men) have to trust me. If anything happens to me, I don't want them to blame themselves.

" 'I wish you could come and get me. I need you. Just come and get me now, honey'.

" 'I wish I could', I said, tears running down my face. 'But I can't. You've got to stop talking like this, you're just tired. You can push for 48 hours'. 'I need to speak to Laird,' he said. I handed Laird the phone and he went upstairs and they talked.

"When Laird gave the phone back, Oz said, 'I'm calm, honey, but I can't help how I feel. I don't think I'm coming back, 'cos I'm cuffing it now. I'm drained  it's hard to explain'.

"The next day I kept the phone beside me all evening, hoping he'd ring. I wanted to ring him but I couldn't, so that night I emailed  'Please email me, Don't go out on the ground tomorrow, cut the last day, don't do it.' He never got it."

That night Christina had a visitation in her dreams from another hero bomb hunter, Warrant Officer Gary "Gaz" O'Donnell, who had perished in the Afghan badlands disarming a Taliban device.

She writes: "I slept fitfully then I dreamed that Gaz O'Donnell was standing in front of me. 'Don't worry, Chris, I'm here to get him when he comes over,' he said. 'I'll hold him. I won't let go'.

" 'What are you on about?' I said. 'You've got no arms'. Gaz just looked at me and smiled.

"The next morning, Saturday October 31, 2009, I woke at 6.30am with a feeling I'd never had before. It was as powerful as thunder.

" 'It's today', I thought. 'He's going or has he gone yet?' I felt it so surely that it was in the floor beneath my feet as I got out of bed and in the air around me as I went downstairs.

"I felt numb, suspended in time, as I went through the motions of life. At nine I phoned my mum and told her I wasn't going to take Laird to his swimming lesson that morning. 'What's going on?' she said. 'You sound so quiet. Oz is home tomorrow, you should be happy'.

"I paused. 'He's not coming home, Mum, I know it'. "

Oz was killed, defusing a bomb, on Halloween while Christina was walking in the woods gathering her thoughts.

At the exact moment he died she wept uncontrollably.

Later in her book Christina reveals more spiritual happenings. She tells how Oz's spirit communicated with her through the spiritualist mum of a friend.

She writes what the spiritualist said: "He's saying, 'Coffee, white, one  man-up'. Oh, and what an awful taste, it's something like liquorice. What is that?' I smiled. 'His liquorice rollies, the menthol tips, he always smoked them. And that's how he talked'. She had his intonation exactly right.

"She always passes on an Oz message in his distinctive style.

"And it helps me to keep going and keeps me grounded."

pages.headline: CPR helped me save lives. Everyone should learn it
pages.teaser: LORD Robert Winston backs Sun campaign for CPR to be taught in British schools
pages.articlebody:
ONE of the world's most respected doctors and scientists is backing The Sun's campaign for all schoolchildren to be taught basic life-saving skills.

Here, he tells us why even more Sun readers should add their names to our petition.

I HAVE resuscitated collapsed colleagues on five separate occasions in the House of Lords.

This was always after they had just completed a speech.

Speaking in that frightening chamber is very stressful.

It is filled with people with extraordinary expertise.

Someone listening will always seem to know more about the subject than the person speaking.

So when a peer gets up to speak, his or her pulse rate frequently rises dramatically.

I am willing to bet that their blood pressure also rises by around 30 per cent.

To sign The Sun-backed British Heart Foundation petition, click here

So it isn't surprising that, when finished, some members simply keel over. Sometimes they literally just faint. But occasionally, they have a cardiac arrest.

As one of a few doctors there when I joined the Lords 17 years ago, I was appalled how poor were the arrangements for these sudden, terrifying emergencies.

The attendant staff had often been trained in mouth-to-mouth and cardiac resuscitation, but there was no defibrillator anywhere in Parliament. This piece of kit is a life-saver.

When its electrodes are applied across the chest, its sudden pulse of high voltage electricity can jolt the heart back into a normal rhythmic beat. It's a clever device because its detector only allows an electric shock if the collapsed patient has had a cardiac arrest or a fatal change of heart rhythm.

So it is safe and exceptionally easy to use by any layman with minimal training.

Yet when I tried to persuade the authorities in Parliament to obtain one of these portable machines (they are not expensive) officials in both Houses refused. Their excuses were shameful.

One official argued that we could not have a defibrillator as it would cause a problem if a tourist collapsed in the gallery  should we be obliged to offer resuscitation to a member of the public? It was suggested there might be legal consequences if it were used or not used. Four years later, an elderly peer collapsed right after speaking. There were no doctors present in the chamber and he died.

Only then, reluctantly, was a defibrillator installed, and since then at least two lives have been saved. Cardiac arrest is extremely common yet it can be correctable. Clearly, it would help if everybody were trained in external cardiac massage, for example in schools. This knowledge would save some lives.

But a clever defibrillator is a different matter. It is astonishing that so many public buildings do not have them readily available.

Those first few seconds after a cardiac emergency are critical and we must be prepared.

pages.teaser: BRITAIN'S biggest brands are going on a "diet"  slashing their calorie count as part of a war on obesity
pages.byline: By EMMA LITTLE, Health Editor and DANIEL JONES, Consumer Editor
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S biggest brands are going on a "diet"  slashing their calorie count as part of a war on obesity.

The number of calories in certain products made by soft drinks giant Coca-Cola will be cut by 30 per cent by 2014.

It will also pump more cash into marketing Diet Coke and Coca-Cola Zero, which contain no sugar, and increase their availability.

Mars bars will be cut from 300 calories to 250, and super-size "Grab Bags" of Walkers crisps, containing 263 calories, will be phased out and replaced with 185-calorie packs.

The move aims to take FIVE BILLION calories a day off Britain's national food and drink intake. More than two-thirds of adults and one in three 11-year-olds are now overweight or obese. Food manufacturers, supermarkets, pubs and caterers joined with the Department of Health yesterday to announce the "Responsibility Deal".

Producers including Hovis and Mr Kipling will slash calorie counts by 30 per cent across a third of their ranges.

Supermarkets will expand their healthy meal ranges and sandwich chain Subway will include five low-fat subs in its £3 lunch offer. Health Secretary Andrew Lansley hailed the plan as "a great step in the right direction," adding: "We all have a role to play."

Diet expert Dr Susan Jebb, of Cambridge University, said: "This programme is vital to tackle obesity. It's a very encouraging start, but it will take time to change the nation's eating habits."

pages.articlebody:
STEPHANIE FOX has something she'd like to get off her chest... her back-breaking, all-natural, size 32K boobs are casting a shadow over her life.

The 21-year-old can't get a boyfriend, can't find clothes to fit and can't even walk down the street without getting an earful of abuse.

Men don't look her in the eye. Girls assume she is a porn star. Then there's the back pain.

She says: "Lots of women want big boobs but it's actually a total nightmare.

"The only men I attract are the sleazy type. It's rare that a guy looks me in the face when talking to me.

"Guys will flat-out stare and try all the cheesy chat-up lines. And a lot of the time they want their picture taken with them. Not me  them."

She adds: "Sometimes it can be a bit scary. A few blokes will try to get really hands-on. When I'm out with my male friends they'll usually circle round me. They're my bodyguards."

Stephanie doesn't fare much better with other girls. She says: "Women assume my boobs are fake  they look at me like I'm a porn star. It's older women who always comment on them.

"They'll tut and shake their heads as they walk past me in the street. I can hear them saying, 'They're so fake', and, 'Look at her flaunting them'.

"I try to smile through it. I know they're real but sometimes it can be hurtful.

"I've developed a way of walking so my boobs bounce up and down and people can see they're real. It looks like I'm walking on the moon.

"Women can get quite jealous  that's probably why I have more male friends."

But meeting the right guy is difficult. Glasgow girl Stephanie says: "I broke up with my ex in 2010. He couldn't handle all the attention I get and became insanely jealous.

"When we were out he'd get mad when other guys checked me out. I tried telling him it couldn't be helped  he knew what he was getting into."

Stephanie has seen a few men since the split but no one special has caught her eye.

She says: "They become too obsessed with my boobs, it's all they think about. It's hard to find a guy to see past them.

"A lot of blokes are just after me for the status of it, they see it as just another notch on the bedpost.

"I want my boyfriend to see me for me, I'm more than just a pair of boobs. I'm a laid back and a down-to-earth girl and I love to have a laugh." Stephanie's boobs proved something of an overnight sensation when she was just 12.

She recalls: "It was so weird. I was a total cheeseboard then one day I woke up with a C cup. It was really annoying because I loved PE and sport.

"I was really into hurdles and running but my boobs started to restrict me. And as I got bigger, it was harder to find a sports bra."

During one family holiday in America Stephanie and her mum Josie, 51, went in search of one that would fit.

She recalls: "We tried this lingerie shop to get a measurement. I was 19 and about a 30J at that point.

"The staff couldn't believe it. Instead of measuring me they just kept calling more and more staff members out of the back to stare at them."

Stephanie adds: "Finding a bikini is atrocious. Nothing fits me so I have to buy separates. "I'll buy a size 12 for my lower half and a 20 for my top half  but even that's too small and they'll be spilling out all over the place. I also get serious back pain.

"Exercise is a nightmare. To do any exercise I have to wear a bra then a sports bra on top.

"I'll go to my local gym and I just get stared at. Gym clothes are quite tight so the guys will full-on stare."

Stephanie doesn't know how she got her huge boobs  though there is something in her family genes.

She says: "My mum does have big boobs but she's probably more of a DD or an E. But my sister Morena has normal-sized breasts.

"Whenever I visit her she'll say, 'God, Stephanie, can you give me some of your boobs!'"

She adds: "I think my dad and older brothers found it awkward when I blossomed. They didn't like men checking me out on the beach. We went on holiday to Italy last year. We went to a water park and I was getting a lot of male attention. Wives were whacking their husbands over the head for staring."

Stephanie works in her parents' fancy dress shop, where she is able to stitch her clothes to fit. She says: "If I don't adjust tops they swamp me or I just look huge. So I've become quite the seamstress."

As for the future, Stephanie plans to start her own business and says: "I know it sounds weird but I'd love to run my own corn on the cob stall.

"I saw a stall selling sweetcorn when I was 15 and ever since, that's what I've wanted to do. You can have butter and pepper on it and things like that  it would be pretty cool."

And despite all the aggro she gets over her shape, on balance she wouldn't want to downsize.

She says: "A part of me loves the attention. They're a great talking point and I get to meet a lot of people. But the downsides probably outweigh that one positive.

"And even the attention can be a double-edged sword. Some days I just don't want to be stared at."

By CAROL COOPER, Sun Doctor

ABNORMALLY large breasts can cause a number of problems, mostly due to the sheer weight. They change the way a woman stands, increasing the curvature of the spine and putting extra strain on it.

This makes back and neck pain common. It can be even worse if the woman has to lift anything heavy.

Shoulders can also suffer, with bra straps causing deep grooves from the weight they support. Nerve pain down the arm can occur, sometimes with tingling in the fingers.

Sweating under the breasts is inevitable, so dermatitis and infections are common, with ulceration in bad cases.

Exercise is tricky. Some women wear two bras at once but it is hard to stop breast discomfort.

Adverse comments can make the woman feel very ill at ease and some become stressed and even depressed.

THE MUM of Man City ace Mario Balotelli last night told of her joy at being reunited after giving him up as a child.

Relieved Rose Barwuah, 46, added: "I am happy to see him and he is happy to see me."

The Sun told on Sunday how Rose moved from Italy to the tough estate featured in TV's Shameless to be near the striker, 21, in the hope of rekindling their relationship.

Her £120,000-a-week son  who she handed to a rich foster family when he was two  now often shows up in his white Bentley GT at her £550-a-month rented terrace.

Rose said: "Mario has been over to see me a few times, but he doesn't want people to know I'm here. We don't see each other all the time as he has his life and I have mine.

"He's a private person and it's still early days." She added: "I haven't even been to watch him play football here yet, but I'm very proud of him. I'm thrilled, overjoyed to be here."

Rose and daughter Angel, 13, moved to Manchester's Wythenshawe area just before Christmas. Angel now goes to a local school.

Nineteen years ago in Italy, she and hubby Thomas were advised to hand Mario to foster parents  the Balotellis.

The couple were then living in a tiny flat in Brescia  and claimed the Balotellis turned Mario against them.

pages.articlebody:
GANG members who left a five-year-old girl paralysed after gunning her down in a shop have been found guilty of GBH.

Nathaniel Grant, Kazeem Kolawole and Anthony McCalla were convicted by a jury at the Old Bailey in London of causing grievous bodily harm to little Thusha Kamaleswaran.

She was shot by the thugs as she played in her aunt's shop in South London in March last year.

The nightmare scenes unfolded in March last year as the trio fired blindly into the Stockwell Food and Wine store.

A bullet hit Thusha in the chest and passed through the seventh vertebra of her spine, leaving her wheelchair-bound for life.

Shopper Roshan Selvakumar was shot in the face in the attack, and has been left with bullet fragments permanently lodged in his head.

Callous Grant, Kolawole and McCalla were looking for a rival gang member when Grant mindlessly opened fire into the shop.

Jurors were told that he would have been able to see Thusha as he fired his second shot.

Dramatic CCTV footage was also shown to the jury from inside the store, where Mr Selvakumar can be seen with blood pouring from his head and Thusha lies slumped on the floor.

The three defendants were found guilty of causing grievous bodily harm with intent to Thusha, now six, and Mr Selvakumar.

They were also convicted of attempted murder of their intended victim Roshaun Bryan.

Prosecutor Edward Brown QC told jurors: "The reality of this shooting may be that, whilst there was an intention to kill the suspected rival gang member, the gunman and his accomplices couldn't have cared less if someone else was shot too."

THE two hero soldiers murdered in Helmand yesterday were gunned down by a turncoat Afghan trooper at the main gate to the British HQ.

The traitor opened fire as he tried to trick his way into Our Boys' heavily-fortified headquarters in Lashkar Gah.

He blasted a Royal Marine and a member of the Adjutant General's Corps with his powerful M-16 assault rifle from just THREE YARDS away.

The rogue shooter  who was in full Afghan army uniform  wounded a third Brit before being shot dead by our troops in a rapid firefight.

He was able to get so close to his victims by claiming he had been assigned to provide security for government VIPs arriving from Kabul.

The Taliban said he had been in touch with them and had told them of his intention to kill.

Afghan Army chief Ghulam Farooq Parwani said the traitor had been a soldier for four years. He added: "He got close to the foreign troops and opened fire."

Shocked Defence Secretary Philip Hammond told the Commons: "Our thoughts, as ever, are with the families, for whom this will be a deeply personal tragedy." An urgent inquiry has been launched.

Hours after the Brits were killed an Afghan police officer shot dead a US soldier at a checkpoint in the east of the country.

The shootings are the latest in a series of treacherous attacks in which the Afghan security forces have killed an estimated 79 Nato service personnel and wounded 110 more since 2007.

Armed Forces Minister Nick Harvey said "force protection" was kept under constant review.

A total of 407 British troops have been killed in Afghanistan since 2001.

pages.teaser: FOOTAGE made by murderer was posted to a TV station the day before he was killed
pages.articlebody:
HORRIFIC footage of the shootings carried out by Toulouse terrorist Mohammed Merah has emerged in France.

The video, which was released to broadcaster Al Jazeera, comes after investigators confirmed the serial killer wore a small camera when he murdered a Rabbi, his two children and a schoolgirl.

A week earlier he had filmed his killings of three French soldiers who had fought in Afghanistan.

The footage is said to have been edited into a sickening montage of the murders to a soundtrack of Islamic war songs.

It was sent in a package post-dated March 21  the day before Merah, 23, was shot dead by police following a siege at his home.

The timing raised fears he may have had an accomplice who mailed the package.

Merah's brother Abdelkader, 29, appeared before an anti-terror judge in Paris on Sunday. He has been charged with complicity in murder.

He was remanded in custody after he told police interrogators that he was "very proud" of his brother's actions.

Security chiefs in Paris think the brothers were involved with two local Islamist organisations, Forsane Alizza and a more militant network called Jund al-Khalifah.

The latter is an al-Qaeda splinter group, which says it worked with someone called Youssef the Frenchman.

Investigators are probing whether this was a name used by Merah.

Liam Stacey, 21, has admitted inciting racial hatred after posting vile comments on the microblogging site as the player was being treated.

Muamba, 23, fell to the ground live on TV on March 17 as his Bolton Wanderers team took on Spurs in the FA Cup.

Stacey, a Swansea University biology student, was caught after police were swamped with complaints about his remarks.

The first of his messages began with "LOL. **** Muamba. He's dead!!!"

Other Twitter users then took him to task, which prompted sickening racist comments from Stacey.

Last week he admitted inciting racial hatred when he appeared briefly at Swansea Magistrates' Court.

He was released on conditional bail but warned that all options would be considered when he is sentenced today.

The maximum possible sentence an offender can get for inciting racial hatred is seven years.

Muamba has made an incredible recovery since his heart attack ten days ago and was well enough to watch Match Of The Day over the weekend.

pages.headline: Terror laws axe puts Brits at risk
pages.teaser: TOUGH restrictions had been a 'useful and necessary' weapon against extremists but new rules 'aid fanatics'
pages.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
NATIONAL security HAS been put at risk by the Coalition's decision to axe control orders, the official terrorism watchdog warned yesterday.

In a devastating report, David Anderson insisted the tough restrictions had been a "useful and necessary" weapon against violent extremists.

And he warned their replacement  Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures  were not up to the job. There was fury when the weaker TPIMs were brought in by the Coalition last year.

Mr Anderson said the changes "were motivated by civil liberties concerns".

He added: "They are unlikely to further the requirements of national security  rather the reverse."

Mr Anderson stressed that control orders had been an "effective means of protecting the public from a small number of suspected terrorists who presented a substantial risk to national security".

He said: "Control orders prevented persons believed to be terrorists from travelling overseas."

They also stopped them "maintaining contact with senior al-Qaeda personnel, providing funds, facilitating the travel and training of others and engaging in terrorist-related activity within the UK."

One of the key powers ditched in the switch to TPIMs was the power to relocate terror suspects to different parts of the country.

Mr Anderson said: "The police stated the loss of the power 'will significantly increase challenges we face'."

He also said the fact TPIMs only lasted two years will "strengthen the resolve of a terrorist who  confronted with an order of potentially indefinite length  might have proved more willing to compromise".

Last night Labour called on Home Secretary Theresa May to "take heed".

Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: "The report shows six terror suspects previously relocated, with a number kept out of London, are now allowed to return under the new powers even though they are a continued threat."

A Home Office spokesman insisted: "Our first priority is national security. The TPIM regime provides effective powers."

Labour's surrender on 10 per cent extra cider duty is a triumph for David Cameron.

The Tories also blocked Labour's planned broadband tax.

Not a bad start as the Tories were clear winners on Day One of the election campaign.

In the Commons, Mr Cameron exposed Gordon Brown's weasel words over Labour's jobs tax.

Mr Brown says the business world has been deceived by the Tories into thinking that Labour's National Insurance tax rise will cost jobs.

Business leaders say Mr Brown is patronising, "economically illiterate" and insults their intelligence.

Almost seventy of Britain's biggest employers  including one of Mr Brown's own advisers  say the Tories are RIGHT.

The Sun agrees. Making firms pay more in tax for every person hired means bosses take on fewer workers.

Only in the warped world of Gordon Brown does raising National Insurance help unemployment.

The fed-up business community has washed its hands of union-run Labour.

Employers think that there will be more REAL jobs under the Tories.

Exactly what the country needs to hear.

Blaze heroes

FIREMEN didn't hesitate when they arrived at a blazing block of high-rise flats.

They plunged straight in  and two tragically lost their lives.

The Sun pays tribute to Hampshire fire heroes James Shears and Alan Bannon.

The brave men and women of our emergency services are very special.

When it comes to the crunch, they lay their lives on the line for us.

We are very lucky. We should be grateful and never forget their sacrifice.

Brave champ

TENNIS ace Martina Navratilova faces another tough challenge.

The legendary champ is diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 53.

Not even a superfit athlete like Martina is safe from a cancer that affects women indiscriminately.

Many Sun readers will have a relative or friend who has been struck down.

Cancer survival rates in Britain have improved over the years. But they lag behind much of Europe and America, where Martina is optimistic about her prospects.

Yes, times are tough. But our next Government must do much more to improve our record on survival rates for breast and other cancers.

Brave Martina, who never gave up on court, will not give up on this fight either.

NEARLY 2,200 jobs were axed yesterday as video games chain Game Group collapsed.

Administrators closed 277 of its 610 high street stores  and warned that more could go.

Millions of customers were told gift cards and loyalty card points could no longer be used. Both schemes have been "temporarily suspended" until a buyer is found.

Game, which had launched in seven overseas countries in an "ambitious" expansion, collapsed under huge debts after being clobbered by the supermarkets and downloads.

Experts wrote it off last month when US giant Electronic Arts refused to supply the chain with blockbuster release Mass Effect 3 in a row over credit terms.

Insiders claim Royal Bank of Scotland, Game's main bankers, pulled the plug in a bid to recoup up to £45million debt. RBS sources say they are leading an attempt to save what is left of the chain.

Mike Jervis, of administrator PricewaterhouseCoopers, said: "Our priority is to continue trading the business as normal while we continue to pursue a sale."

More than 170 retailers have collapsed since 2007.

HEARTBROKEN Tammy Driver told last night how she went from bride to battered wife in FOUR DAYS.

Tammy, 21, enjoyed a romantic honeymoon weekend with husband Nicky Pearce, 29.

She thought she had found happiness for life, but when they got home Pearce accused her of flirting with his best man in their local pub.

Drunken Pearce smashed up their wedding gifts then turned on terrified Tammy, grabbing her by the throat, biting her face and breaking her nose. Sobbing Tammy fled the couple's home in Penrhiwceiber, South Wales, and went to hospital. She never went back to Pearce and said: "He promised to love me and take care of me for the rest of my life. But it was a nightmare."

Tammy, who feared she would DIE in the attack, added: "The vows we took four days earlier meant nothing to him  I didn't know this man.

"Everything was great on honeymoon, really romantic. But when we got home he flew into a rage. I thought he was the perfect man to spend the rest of my life with, but it was all shattered by the next weekend."

Pearce was jailed for a year at Merthyr Tydfil Crown Court after admitting assault. Tammy now has a new man. She added: "I was lucky to get out of my marriage in one piece."

A BANK manager who bit off part of a man's ear was jailed yesterday.

Samantha Williams, 28, attacked Gary Bedler, 39, as he drank outside a hotel with three stag party pals  one wearing a mankini.

A friend of Williams chatted to the men before the bank boss suddenly bit off the top part of Mr Bedler's left ear.

He was rushed to hospital in Salisbury, Wilts, but doctors could not reattach the bitten flesh.

A PASSENGER in a hot air balloon which blew into power cables in a hail of sparks said last night: "It was like being in a firework."

Colin Jiggle, a female passenger and teenage pilot Adam Griffiths were hanging 45ft above ground for FIVE HOURS before they could be rescued.

Yesterday Colin, 52, said: "We'd had a very serene flight. I have a pilot's licence but never been in a balloon before. When we went into the lines and the pylon there was a lot of sparks. They burnt my jacket. It was like being in a firework."

The balloon struck the 132,000-volt cables in a field in Bozeat, Northants, just after 6pm on Sunday.

Pilot Adam Griffiths, 18, suffered minor burns. He said: "There was quite a bang and a little bit of a fire in the basket, but it put itself out as I went to grab the fire extinguisher. We slid down the power line and came to a standstill."

They were rescued after the electricity was turned off. It will be switched on when the balloon is finally untangled.

pages.subdeck: Skin kin ... some of the 16 albino members of the Parvez family from Coventry who are set to be Guinness World Record holders
pages.headline: The fairest of them all
pages.teaser: 16-STRONG Asian family from the West Midlands are all white-skinned with fair hair
pages.articlebody:
THE world's biggest albino family is living in the UK, it was revealed last night.

White-skinned couple Aslam Parvez, 55, and wife Shameem, 56, are the eldest of the 16-strong clan from Coventry.

The Asian family, who live within five miles of one another, are all are white-skinned with white hair.

They have difficulty seeing in strong light and are unable to sit in bright sunshine for more than ten minutes because their skin burns so easily.

All of the couple's six children  daughters Naseem, 33, Mukadas, 27, and Musarat, 20, and sons Ghulam, 31, Haider Ali, 29, and Mohammed, 18  have inherited the genetic condition.

Two of Aslam's brothers and a sister have the condition too.

His three siblings have five albino children between them  making them the biggest albino family in the world.

Revealing a fascinating insight into their lives, eldest son Ghulam told how, despite difficulties as they grew up, they have never let their albinism get them down.

He said: "Growing up was hard for all of us. No one wants to look so different and with our pale skins and white hair we really stood out.

"Of course, we were teased when we went out of the house. And even now if we all go out together our unusual looks make people stop and stare.

"But people in the local area are used to us and we have always been accepted by the Muslim community.

"Perhaps having this condition has made us particularly close as a family. But thankfully, as there's so many of us, we've never felt lonely."

This month The Sun revealed that the largest albino family was thought to be the ten-strong Pullan family, from Delhi, India.

But now Guinness World Records have told the Parvez family they would be verifying that they had the record.

Incredibly, until Aslam, a retired mechanic, was born in the Fifties no one had any idea the condition existed in the family.

Ghulam said: "My dad's parents, both originally from Pakistan, were normal brown-skinned Muslims.

"In fact, their first two children  both girls  were absolutely fine.

"Then my dad was born with the condition and out of nine brothers and sisters, three others were also born as albinos.

"Then no one really understood why his parents had so many albino children.

"But with genetic research we now know that, although they both looked normal, both my grandad and his wife carried the albino gene."

When Aslam was 11 his family moved from Pakistan to the UK.

Then the time came for him to get married and he and his brother, who both had arranged marriages, were matched with Shameem and her sister.

They came from a different family but also both had albinism.

Ghulam said: "My mum and dad felt so lucky to find one another.

"Mum has said she did worry when she was young that because she was albino she wouldn't be able to marry.

"So she was thrilled when her parents said they'd managed to match not only her but her sister as well with two brothers who were also albino.

"As they all had the same pale skin and white hair, it seemed obvious that they fitted together as a match.

"It truly seemed a miracle  and when they met it was like looking at a mirror image of one another.

"It definitely helped because both of them understood what it was like to be albino and it meant they weren't alone.

"Back then, no one understood the genetics or that if an albino married an albino, they would definitely have albino children.

"Now we understand more and knew that if we married someone with normal brown skin then our children would not be albino."

As a family they all have the eyesight problems which are common in albinos.

Ghulam  who is an IT expert but unemployed at the moment  added: "We are always squinting in the daylight and our eyesight is very poor.

"It's difficult to see more than a few metres ahead, yet wearing contact lenses makes the light glare even worse.

"In the summer we can wear sunglasses. Otherwise, many of us wear hats to keep the light from hurting our eyes."

Ghulam, who is married to Najma, 33, who has normal brown skin, also told how some people do not believe he is the biological dad to his daughter Sidra Begum, ten, and son Ahmed, eight.

Because his wife does not carry the albino gene, his son and daughter were born with the same colour skin as hers.

Ghulam said: "When my son was a baby I often got strange looks from passers-by because I was this white man with a brown-skinned baby.

"Even now at school my son says children sometimes ask him why he has such a white dad.

"It's quite hard to explain why, so I just tell him to say I am special and he seems happy with that.

"Apart from our skin colour, we do look the same. You can tell we are related. We have the same facial characteristics and ears."

Unusually, his nephew Asad has a white streak in his hair, the only sign of albinism in him.

Ghulam explained: "My sister was amazed when her son was born with a white streak.

"When he was a newborn baby he had a white patch on his head and everyone thought it was a birthmark.

"Then the hair there began to grow white and he now has a white streak in his dark hair.

"No one can understand how that has happened."

The family are definitely special, though.

Ghulam added: "We are quite sure we are unique in the UK. And although we've read about other albino families abroad, we haven't even heard of any family with so many with the same condition."

Until the Pullan and Parvez families turned up, the world record was shared by two families.

Both six-strong, one lives in the US and the other in Canada.

But the Parvez family are on track to take the world record now.

Albino facts



Albinism affects around one in 17,000 people from all ethnic backgrounds.

For a baby to be born albino, both parents must carry the albino gene.

If both parents do carry the gene, there is a one in four chance that their baby will inherit the condition.

Children born to parents who do not have the condition are often carriers.

The term albinism is derived from the Latin word albus, meaning white.

myView



By PROFESSOR ANDREW READ, Geneticist

ALBINOS are people who cannot produce melanin, the dark pigment that colours our skin, hair and eyes.

The problem is genetic. Curiously, it also affects the way the eyes are wired up to the brain, so albinos also have vision problems.

We all have two copies of that gene, one inherited from each of our parents.

If even one copy works, you can make melanin and look normal.

But if two people marry, each with one defective copy, there is a one in four chance that a child would inherit both non-working genes and be born albino.

Albinism affects both sexes  and all races.

It's especially striking when it affects normally dark-skinned African people.

Albinism is only one of several different genetic conditions that can affect pigmentation.

But the pink eyes and poor vision make it special.

DRIVERS are pictured on a death crash motorway using phones, maps and even a LAPTOP at the wheel.

A Sun probe found truckers, van drivers and other motorists on the M5 chatting into mobiles and fiddling with their sat navs.

Some were poring over maps or documents and gulping from steaming cups of coffee.

Many took their eyes off the road to look down while several even took both HANDS off the wheel to stretch and adjust clothes.

The shocking photos were taken on the M5, one of Britain's busiest routes  the same motorway where two men died following a collision between a lorry and a coach near Halesowen, West Midlands, last Saturday.

Seven people were killed and 51 were injured following a massive 30-car pile-up on the M5 near Bridgwater, Somerset, last November. We snapped drivers on the stretch of the motorway in nearby Taunton.

An RAC spokesman said: "Clearly, taking your hands off the wheel while driving creates unnecessary risk and increases the possibility of accidents. We advise all drivers to pay attention to what is going on around them at all times."

Almost 25,000 people were killed or seriously injured in over 38,000 accidents on British roads in the 12 months to last September.

pages.headline: Dubai booze session boy's death plunge
pages.teaser: COPS trying to discover how he fell after night out with pals
pages.articlebody:
COPS were last night trying to discover how a British schoolboy plunged 11 floors to his death after drinking in Dubai.

Harry Harling, 15, who lived there with his ex-pat family, had spent the night with pals.

He returned home in the early hours of Saturday  and then mysteriously fell from a balcony on a building site.

The rugby-mad Year 11 pupil  who studied at Jumeirah College in the UAE  said on Twitter before heading out: "Beers and tanning with the lads justwhatIneed."

But his puzzling last tweet read: "F*** the system."

Grieving pal Harry Francis spoke of his guilt after leaving his chum on the night out. He wrote of Facebook: "Mate I'm so sorry, I should of never left you alone on Friday. I should of stayed with you till you got a taxi.

"I hope you can find it in your heart to forgive me." Another friend, James Ozden, replied by saying: "Everyone is thinking of ways they could have changed the outcome but its not fair for you to blame yourself!"

Last night his mum Beverley, 46, dad Nicolus, 49 and 19-year-old sister Rebecca were struggling to come to terms with his death. The family, originally from Woking, Surrey, moved to Dubai nine years ago.

College principal Fiona Cottam said counselling was being offered to shocked pupils and staff.

CID chief Major General Khalil al Mansouri said Harry had just left a party on Friday night where there was "drinking". Police are investigating but he said it was not a criminal inquiry.

It is not known how Harry was able to buy alcohol in Dubai, where the legal drinking age is 21. Strict Muslim laws mean it can be bought only in hotels or bars owned by hotels.

The Foreign Office said: "We are aware of the death of a British minor in Dubai and are providing consular assistance."

FALKLAND Islanders facing an "economic blockade" by Argentina are being helped... by URUGUAY.

Argentina's near neighbour is offering to fly bottled water and freight into the British outpost  dashing Argie hopes to cut it off from the world.

The move will infuriate Argie president Cristina Kirchner.

She has called for Latin American countries to turn away ships flying the Falkland flag  triggering food shortages and rising prices in the Falklands.

But an email seen by the Sun shows a Uruguayan airline is offering to fly a cargo plane to the islands in TWO WEEKS.

Guillermo Wild, head of the British Chambers of Commerce in Uruguay, said the offer followed publicity of a recent trade mission to the islands.

He said: "This led to a number of Uruguayan companies to come forward offering their products for the Falkland Islands.

"A cargo flight offered by a local airline is schedueled for the 13th of April. The plane is at this time flying empty but is basically offering its cargo services to and from the FIs to anyone that could be interested."

Mr Wild was unavailable for comment yesterday.

Argentina earlier this week called for a twice-weekly flight from Chile to the Falklands to be scrapped  and replaced by one it would control.

pages.teaser: IMMIGRANTS given student visas in 2009 and 2010, but may not have attended college
pages.articlebody:
UP to 50,000 foreign students went missing because of a major UK Border Agency blunder, it is revealed today.

The National Audit Office said the immigrants were given student visas in 2009 and 2010, but may not have attended college.

An NAO report said the UKBA switched to a new system "before key controls were in place".

It claimed staff "did not check" if those granted visas became students. NAO chief Amyas Morse said: "The flaws were predictable and avoidable."

Nearly 300,000 foreign students and their families are given visas every year.

Labour introduced supposedly harsher restrictions in 2009, with foreign students having to be sponsored by colleges and banned from moving between institutions.

But between February 2010 and October 2011, 62,000 foreign students were still reported for not attending classes.

An NAO contractor took just a week to track down around 200 "lost" people.

The NAO also claimed the Border Agency did "little" to kick out students whose requests for extensions are refused. Just 2,900 have been deported since 2009.

Immigration Minister Damian Green said the Coalition is "stamping out abuse" of the system.

pages.headline: Tulisa ex: Sex tape her idea
pages.teaser: RAPPER MC Ultra  real name Justin Edwards  broke his silence over tape
pages.byline: By EMILY NASH and GARY O'SHEA
pages.articlebody:
THE former boyfriend of Tulisa Contostavlos broke his silence over their infamous sex tape yesterday and insisted it was HER idea.

Rapper MC Ultra  real name Justin Edwards  denied releasing the explicit footage, which shows the X Factor judge in an intimate moment with him.

He also backed a legal ban on the clip and said it should never have been made public.

In a statement read to London's High Court, Edwards, 28, said: "I am disgusted it has been, and regret ever allowing the claimant to persuade me that we should film ourselves."

He maintained he would not have published the clip  adding: "Simply because I would find it ungentlemanly. I was brought up better than that."

After the hearing, Edwards exclusively told The Sun: "I'm just relieved to have a chance to tell my side of the story.

"It can't happen soon enough. I've had to move out of my home and it's been a nightmare for my family.

"I just want this sorted out so I can move on with my life."

Last Friday Edwards was slapped with a £100,000 claim for damages for alleged breach of privacy and confidentiality by Tulisa, who accused him of leaking the six-minute video.

But yesterday he suggested the footage  published online last week  was filmed on the N-Dubz star's phone and denied he'd ever owned it.

His statement read: "I simply do not, and never have, possessed the film referred to."

Yet Tulisa's QC Desmond Browne told Mr Justice Tugendhat the singer had been "the victim of a vindictive act of betrayal by Mr Edwards  seemingly motivated by personal spite and financial greed".

He called the rapper's denial that he passed on the sex tape "hypocrisy" and "a deceitful representation of the position".

Tulisa, 23, won an injunction last week after the video appeared on the net for downloads.

In a preliminary hearing yesterday Mr Justice Tugendhat extended the ban on anyone using, publishing, communicating or disclosing the clip to any other person.

A date for the next hearing has not yet been set.

pages.articlebody:
POLICE found a woman intruder on a SHELF in Simon Cowell's wardrobe, it emerged last night.

The Sun revealed yesterday how the X Factor boss was confronted by a female wielding a brick when he rushed to investigate after hearing a noise at his home.

A woman appeared in court yesterday as further details of Saturday night's incident emerged.

Cowell, 52, came face-to-face with the intruder, who was standing on a flat roof shouting and holding a brick above her head after breaking his bathroom window, sources revealed.

The woman is said to have told Cowell's shocked staff: "Simon knows me."

Armed police were called and found her hiding on a shelf 7ft up in Cowell's walk-in wardrobe. They also reported blood stains by the broken window.

It is believed she uncovered details of Cowell's West London home after researching it online.

Cowell tightened his security yesterday, adding extra bodyguards to the team that protect him 24/7. A source said: "It's a shame as he prides himself on being a man of the people, but he just can't take chances."

Leanne Zaloumis, 29, of Catford, South East London, appeared at West London Magistrates Court accused of aggravated burglary. The charge claims she intended to inflict GBH. She spoke only to confirm her personal details as she was remanded in custody until June.

pages.headline: Matthew Wolfenden: I'm celebrating my win with a trip to the hospital
pages.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: DANCING On Ice champ is marking victory by getting TWO MRI scans
pages.articlebody:
DANCING On Ice champion Matthew Wolfenden is marking his victory  with a visit to hospital for TWO MRI scans.

The Emmerdale star beat Jorgie Porter and Chico Slimani in Sunday night's final but the gruelling competition has left him suffering a catalogue of injuries.

Between rehearsals with his ice partner Nina Ulanova, Matthew kept up working five days a week playing David Metcalfe in the ITV soap.

He told TV Biz: "I've bust both my tendons in my ankles. I've had my feet in a bucket of ice every day for weeks to take the pain down.

"I can't lift my right arm properly so I'm going for an MRI scan on Tuesday. I think it's to do with my rotator cuff.

"Then when I have the MRI scan on my shoulder, I need to have one on my knee too because when I dropped Nina out of the headbanger in training, I landed on my knee and I've ripped all the bits in the back of it.

"My back and wrist hurts from the lifts and I've done my groin in.

"I've got a week off the ice to let everything relax, then the tour starts. But I've no time off work."

Matthew trained to be a gymnast from the age of four but had to quit the British team after breaking his back in a fall from the rings aged 17. Due to the stress of training, his old spinal injury flared up again.

He said: "It's definitely affected me on Dancing On Ice. I've had back problems since week two when I trapped a nerve."

Partner Nina added: "He'll never admit it but he is in a lot of pain." The injury to his shoulder is so bad that Matthew thinks he would have LOST if the competition had gone on for another week.

On Sunday night's show the judges could see him struggling to get Nina above his head and Matthew said: "Midway through the competition those lifts were popping up dead easily and yesterday it was really hard.

"I don't think I'd have coped with the lifts if we'd had one more week to go. If the final had been next week then I think we'd have had to take all the lifts out."

Nina also got a share of injuries throughout the series. Not only did Matthew repeatedly drop her as he practised his lifts, he also slashed her leg open with the toe picks on his boots, leaving her with a huge scar.

He said: "We put in blood, sweat and tears  lots of blood."

Matthew and Hollyoaks star Jorgie had to pull off three routines in the final  a showcase dance, their favourite routine from the series and their version of Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean's Bolero dance. Show judges and Olympians Katarina Witt and Robin Cousins said Matthew could have been an international ice skating champ if he had started at a young age.

Now he is hoping to get his toddler son Buster  whose mum is Matthew's co-star fiancée Charley Webb  to try ice skating.

Matthew said: "Our northern coach, Stephen Pickavance, told me, 'You should have done this as a kid, you'd have gone so far.'

"I'm definitely going to get Buster on the ice now this has all finished because it's brilliant and he'll love it.

"Now I can whizz him around and I feel confident enough. It will be great."

Matthew thought he would never win a sporting trophy again after his gymnastic career was over, but winning Dancing On Ice is a great consolation prize.

He said: "It was amazing to win in an Olympic year. This makes up for the gymnastics a little bit. Training was my life until I had my accident and broke my back."

Matthew has been a huge hit with fans on Dancing On Ice but he insists he will never quit his soap role.

He said: "I don't want to leave Emmerdale. It's my bread and butter and they've been so accommodating throughout this whole show.

"Everyone at Emmerdale is just brilliant. I've signed a contract that takes me to Christmas then, hopefully, I'll get a new one after that too."

Matthew revealed he has a huge storyline coming up  and hinted that David's ex-girlfriend Leyla Harding (Rokhsaneh Ghawam-Shahidi) could be returning to cause trouble for him.

He said: "I've got a big new storyline. It's to do with Alicia and David and the little one, Jacob.

"Maybe Leyla might mess things up and come back  but I can't tell you if she will or not!"

pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S Got Talent hopeful Sam Kelly has revealed the secret behind his heartfelt audition  his cheating ex.

The talented 19-year-old  who wowed the BGT panel with his cover of Adele's Make You Feel My Love  told how he tapped into painful memories of his former girlfriend.

Sam told TV Biz: "I am currently single, my last girlfriend cheated on me. She is not a very nice person actually, so it is probably a good thing.

"It is quite a while ago but the keen sting of that still hasn't gone away."

After hearing Sam's emotional performance with his guitar, judge David Walliams told him: "I think when you tackle a song like that, it's not just your voice  it's the way you make us believe you've lived every line of that song. I was completely blown away."

pages.articlebody:
BIG talents Jonathan Antoine and Sam Buttery will be battling for the nation's hearts following their performances on BGT and The Voice.

Opera fan Jonathan, 17, was a star of his ITV show after belting out Celine Dion and Andrea Bocelli's The Prayer in a duet with his close friend Charlotte Jaconelli.

Sam, 20  picked to be one of Tom Jones' acts on The Voice  blasted BGT over some of the entrants it features.

He said: "What put me off applying is that they show good AND bad people. I don't like looking at the bad."

Student Sam claimed his success was one in the eye for his doubters.

He said: "Some people have said I can't sing. But Tom Jones says I can  so jog on!"

Talent is a turn on



Our graph shows The Voice began with a 5.2million audience  which grew to 9.8million.

When BGT came on for the last 20 minutes, the BBC 1 hit kept an average 8.9million viewers against 6.7million.

Within minutes of The Voice's end, four million had switched to BGT  helping it to an 11.5million peak and a larger overall audience.

Beeb's ahead by 3m in fight



BBC bosses claimed a proud victory in Britain's biggest ever reality TV war  after The Voice beat BGT by THREE MILLION viewers while the two shows went head-to-head.

And last night even BGT boss Simon Cowell conceded the Beeb's £22million show made a "great start".

Peak audience for The Voice was an impressive 9.8million  still some way short of BGT's 11.5million Saturday night high point.

But the BBC newcomer made mincemeat of its rival for the 20 minutes that the shows overlapped.

While BGT started at 8pm with 5.9million viewers, The Voice was still being watched by 9.3million after an hour on air.

Beeb chiefs were delighted with the figures  way higher than the six to seven million some executives privately expected.

It also trounced the 2007 launch of BGT, which averaged only five million viewers, the same figure The X Factor got on its 2004 debut.

Yet despite The Voice's strong start, ITV's peak audience figure was 600,000 more than that for last year's launch show.

It also bagged a further 700,000 viewers on the ITV1 plus 1 service.

Cowell said: "They had a great start. We had a great start. But to use a football analogy, it's only the first five minutes of a 90-minute match. It's early days."

AS BBC bigwigs popped their champagne corks last night they had only one person to thank for bumper ratings for The Voice  Simon Cowell.

That their great rival would become their great saviour will not be lost on the Beeb's spin doctors, desperate for awareness of their new show.

After all, this was never a reality TV war until Simon decided it was one.

He changed the date of the BGT opener to clash with The Voice knowing it would rattle the BBC  which cried foul and the finger-pointing began.

But the ensuing mud-slinging only helped fuel the public appetite for this all-new format.
