pages.subdeck: Go coach ... Jessie J is relishing her role on BBC show The Voice
pages.headline: Jessie J: I'm all about The Voice
pages.teaser: FEISTY pop star Jessie J could have ended up on Britain's Got Talent if her pals had had their way
pages.articlebody:
SHE'S the BBC's feisty new star but Jessie J could easily have ended up on The Voice's bitter rival Britain's Got Talent if her pals had had their way.

Speaking to The Sun as £22million talent show The Voice opened on Saturday night, she confessed she caused a stir by snubbing Simon Cowell's shows.

The singer, real name Jessica Cornish, admits: "A lot of people were, like, 'Why aren't you doing Britain's Got Talent or The X Factor?'

"But I think it's really important in your career to pick things that really represent you as a person."

Her putdown of X Factor comes despite her turn as a mentor during the judges' houses stage of last year's show, when she teamed up with Tulisa in Greece. Cowell has admitted he is a huge fan of hers.

But Londoner Jessie was the first big name to sign up as a coach on The Voice, the BBC's most hyped entertainment show in more than a decade.

She reckons it was an easy decision for her to join the show because the super-ambitious singer  who trained at the celebrity fast-track academy, London's Brit School  wanted people to see another side to her.

She says: "It's very scary but very exciting. But you know what? I'm just excited because I get to see a different side of things and people get to see me in a completely different scenario.

"I'm not singing and it's not me doing a three-minute TV performance, so people get to see my personality and really see that I have a passion for what I do. That's what I'm most excited about, people getting to see that I am a bit silly, make jokes and get told off.

"But I'm also a hard worker and care about technique and the artist, and I get very emotional."

Discussing her bisexuality, she says: "I've been with guys and I've been with girls and I kind of think it's about the person, not the genitals."

We revealed earlier this month how tattooed Jessie has been enjoying secret dates with rapper Tinie Tempah  another ridiculously talented artist.

Jessie, who has endured teasing about her bisexuality  not least from her two older sisters who are married with kids  suffers from a hereditary heart defect which caused her skin to go GREEN when she was younger and earned her the nickname "alien".

And at the Brit School, where she played in a girl band, she was struck down by a minor stroke just a few months before graduation, which forced her to drop out.

Some say her health issues have helped to keep her grounded in an industry full of sharks and phonies.

She has enjoyed a string of hits  notably Price Tag and Do It Like A Dude  but believes she can connect with the The Voice's contestants because she still feels their fears about the fickle public.

She says of starting on the show: "It's a very interesting vibe and I just found myself forgetting I was on TV. But I could understand what the contestants were going through, stepping on stage and wanting to get people's attention. It broke my heart.

"It's a weird situation because I'm still in that situation as a recording artist right now. I could put out my second album and no one could buy it. I desperately want people to buy it so know how that feels.

"I'm very protective of my artists.But one thing I made clear at auditions is that they shouldn't feel defeated. You've just performed on a massive studio stage and got to sing in front of the whole of the UK. It's a once-in-a-lifetime sort of thing."

Ironically, for someone whose unique look marks her out from the crowd, part of the reason Jessie wanted to do The Voice was that it is NOT about appearances  the panel sitting with their backs to the acts so they judge on only the voice.

She says: "It's not about what the acts are wearing. Your look is not definitive.

"It's very important to try to look your best. I love getting dressed up and making an effort. All that is part of it, but it's also about you doing it for the right reasons.

"It's about knowing, when you're a singer, that you can wear the greatest outfit but, if you're not breathing right or holding the mic right, you're not going to perform well and be seen as the voice  you're going to be seen as the clothes.

"The thing that made me agree to get involved with The Voice is that it's about the one thing I'm all about  the voice."

The chemistry between Jessie and her fellow coaches  Tom Jones, Black Eyed Peas frontman Will.i.am and The Script singer Danny O'Donoghue  made for entertaining viewing on Saturday, although the show lacked some of The X Factor's edge.

Before The Voice launched, the judges were sent on a a night out together to get to know each other  just the four of them, no flunkeys allowed. Jessie says: "We went out for dinner. I'd flown in from Thailand that morning and was really tired.

"I was, like, 'This is the most surreal meal of my life. Tom Jones is asking what everyone wants as a appetiser.' I was, like, 'Oh-kay!'

"So I just started to talk, then I realised I really am like a big sponge that just soaks everything up, from being on the show to being around people like Tom.

"You feel like you've known him for years within five minutes.

"I remember him for Not Unusual and Sex Bomb but everyone knows who he is, even if you don't really know his music. He's just one of those names that's always been up there with, you know, UK talent. To hear him talking  'Oh, when I was at Elvis Presley's house... '  it's not him just name-dropping, that's just him growing up and what happened.

"It was really nice that he's been part of a completely different musical background but he's interested in knowing about the things that I have to do now as an artist.

"I'm stepping into something new but he's also stepping into something new and we're both coming from different places.

"All of us are learning from each other. It's very nice, very humbling, to be accepted by someone like Tom Jones and for him to go, 'Jessie, how do you think I should sing this bit?'

"We all have really healthy debates."

He adds: "I would hate if it were an obscene and gratuitous, like how some celebrities get intruded upon.

"I can handle it as it is. A nice trickle of people just gently boosting my ego."

Hiding an ego behind a series of animated phone pranks must be tough though. For Kayvan's major break came through the TV series Fonejacker - where his identity was left hidden.

Which is why it was nice to make the move from 'Fone' to 'Face'.

He says: "It was nice to break cover. Plus the fact that people liked my work before knowing what I looked like was helpful."

And when people do find out what Kayvan looks like, they can be pleasantly surprised.

I put it to the funnyman that he is a hearthrob.

Embarrassed, he says: "Well, it helps that I'm not deformed I suppose."

Aside from Facejacking and popping up in films, Kayvan has starred in medical drama Sirens with Rhys Thomas (Star Stories) and Richard Madden (Game of Thrones).

The series is out on DVD now. But what is Kayvan's real-life experience of A&E?

"Last time I went to A&E was to visit my father, who became injured after being chased down the road by a tramp.

"There is a lesson to be learned there - if a tramp thinks you're being rude to their dog, ignore them.

WAYNE ROONEY'S winner lifted Manchester United back to the top of the table  but even boss Alex Ferguson admitted they got lucky.

"Everyone in the stadium expected a penalty and the ref would have had to send Carrick off.

"We could have shocked them, they looked very nervous."

Ferguson admitted: "Fulham finished the game very strongly and caught us out on the counter-attack.

"We started giving the ball away and it was disappointing not to finish them off.

"But we played well for 60 minutes and it's a very good win for us.

"Over the years I don't know how many times I've said 1-0 is a great result. It means championship form."

Di Matteo added: "We're engaged with the FA but ultimately someone has to make the call."

pages.subdeck: WAYNE'S WORLD ... Wayne Rooney celebrates as United go back to the top
pages.headline: Man Utd 1 Fulham 0
pages.teaser: WHEN Alex Ferguson ends up down by the United touchline jabbing his watch you know the bum is squeaky
pages.articlebody:
THAT was just a bit too close for Manchester United.

When Alex Ferguson ends up down by the touchline jabbing his watch you know the bum is squeaky.

Having dominated against a club who have won at Old Trafford just once in 49 years, his side could count themselves fortunate to have come away with all three points.

They had controlled possession and ensured Fulham keeper Mark Schwarzer was Man of the Match with the saves they forced him into.

And yet, and yet...

With two minutes left, Michael Carrick's challenge in the area on Danny Murphy should have resulted in a penalty.

It was a big call that ref Michael Oliver simply could not make.

You can only imagine what Manchester City fans were shouting at their TV screens having tuned in with hope.

United were off the hook  and how big could that decision be.

In a title race as fantastic as this, it seems the tension is going to grab both clubs.

It gripped the Red Devils as they too often played the wrong final ball.

It gripped them when Carrick made a challenge he did not need to at the end.

But the stats will show that Wayne Rooney's 42nd-minute goal decided it.

Red Devils fans will enjoy the look of the Premier League table this morning more than the closing minutes of last night's match.

United now lead not by goal difference but by a full three points... a game.

They have shifted into pole position.

But if Fulham at home can bring a bead of sweat to the brow, nothing is certain.

A club with the worst away record in the Premier League and they nearly grabbed a point. But Rooney's 28th goal of the season in all competitions  and 11th in nine games  keeps United's relentless pursuit of the title going.

Since back-to-back defeats at the turn of the year, they have won nine games and drawn one.

They have clung on to City's coat-tails then overhauled them.

As boss Ferguson himself said: "We are in the right place at the right time and, most importantly, with the right players.

"We have the right players to make a really determined effort to lead over the last lap and go all the way. Our guys have been flogging away and perhaps wondering if they would ever catch up before we hit the finishing line.

"The players deserve the recognition that goes with being leaders."

If they want to stay there, Fergie will want to see his players taking their chances better than they did last night  and also providing a better final ball.

Before Rooney's goal, the men in red were flapping their arms at each other in frustration at the choices made by individuals when in possession.

Ryan Giggs had an early header held. Antonio Valencia nimbly swapped passes with Danny Welbeck before having a shot charged down.

Patrice Evra put an overhead kick just wide.

And moments later a brilliant flick from Valencia found Rafael.

But his finish was woeful and Welbeck  waiting in the middle  let him know it.

When Evra hit a cross into the box that caught Stephen Kelly on the upper arm, United's French left-back jumped up and down in despair as no penalty was awarded.

United were starting to get fractious  but salvation was just a minute away.

Ashley Young crossed from the left and when both Rooney and Brede Hangeland missed with attempted headers, the ball bounced off a startled John Arne Riise.

Jonny Evans was on to it and turned the ball back for Rooney to fire home from close range.

You thought the floodgates would then open.

And United did go looking for the key after the break as they set up camp in Fulham's half.

Valencia and Young both had stinging volleys superbly stopped.

But as the minutes clicked down, Fulham sensed an edginess fill this famous ground. Fill the terraces and the play of their opponents.

They decided to have a go and when Murphy found his way into the box, Carrick kicked his ankle and sent his foot on to the ball.

Maybe it was that which deceived the referee as Murphy went down.

But when even Red Devil-turned-TV pundit Gary Neville says it should have been a pen against United at Old Trafford, you know it was a pen.

We are told these things even themselves out.

Don't say that to a City fan.

pages.headline: Mick won't close door on Wolves
pages.teaser: MICK McCARTHY is leaving the door open for an amazing return as Molineux manager
pages.articlebody:
MICK McCARTHY is leaving the door open for a sensational return as Wolves manager.

He was sacked last month following a disastrous 5-1 home defeat to Black Country rivals West Brom.

But the struggling Molineux club have hit rock-bottom in the Premier League since McCarthy's No 2 Terry Connor was handed the job.

And McCarthy, 53, has not ruled out the possibility of a shock return.

He admitted: "I would never say never, that's all I can say. Stranger things have happened in football  Carlos Tevez, for example, is back playing for Manchester City."

Norwich boss Paul Lambert insisted last week that Wolves were wrong to sack McCarthy.

But McCarthy added: "Ideally, I'm looking forward to a fresh challenge.

"I think Wolves could be a challenge for somebody else  I've done my time."

McCarthy also insisted he parted on good terms with Wolves owner Steve Morgan, who stormed into the dressing room to blast the players after they lost at home to Liverpool.

Former Republic of Ireland boss McCarthy added: "He made the decision to get shot of me, but that happens.

"I'm not bitter and twisted about it. My relationship with Steve was good and remains good now."

pages.subdeck: URGENT NEED ... Lampard says Chelsea need more passion
pages.headline: Lampard and Di Matteo disagree
pages.teaser: BOSS Di Matteo says Blues are good enough  even if ace Lampard publicly doubts it
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO DI MATTEO reckons Chelsea are in good shape  even if his own midfield star Frank Lampard disagrees.

But both the Blues interim boss and the veteran campaigner, 33, are united in their drive to knock Benfica out of the Champions League.

The first leg of the quarter-final takes place in Lisbon's Estadio Da Luz tonight  with the lead up to the game dominated by Lampard's opinions and what Di Matteo thought of them.

Lampard told Chelsea's own TV station that the Blues were not as good as they once were and that their position of fifth in the league was not good enough.

He also argued they had lost their aura of invincibility at Stamford Bridge after what he felt was a poor display in the 0-0 draw at home to Spurs last Saturday.

And he called on Chelsea to produce in Europe again and perform like they did to get through the last round where they overturned a 3-1 first-leg deficit against Napoli to win the second-leg 4-1.

Lampard said: "The fixtures and where we are in the table doesn't lie  we're not as good as we used to be.

"We used to have a fortress and, for whatever reason, we're just not doing it.

"It's something we must all put right.

"I don't think we were at it enough against Tottenham.

"We had to play more with the urgency we showed against Napoli. Against Tottenham, we didn't really do enough to lift the fans.

"We had the high of Napoli, then we got beaten by Manchester City and now we need to up it again.

"Chelsea should be in the top four. No disrespect to the other top-five clubs but, with the ability we have, we should be in there.

"It is far from over. There is no point being downbeat about it at the minute.

"It's five points and the gap has been bigger than that.

"It's up to us now to get ourselves right for Benfica and the league games coming up."

Chelsea chairman Bruce Buck and chief executive Ron Gourlay looked on as Di Matteo responded  just as they observed Andre Villas Boas in Napoli not long before he was sacked.

And Di Matteo was keen to paint a positive picture of life under his management for the bosses who report to owner Roman Abramovich.

He said: "We've had a difficult season. The numbers say that, so there is no point in denying it.

"But we have quality in this team and many good players. I still think this Chelsea team is a very good team.

"Chelsea used to be in the top two or top three, at least.

"So it's been hard for us, domestically.

"But we're in the semi-finals of a domestic cup, and in the quarter-finals of the Champions League.

"I have faith in this team. They've shown they can play at high intensity at a high level, so I'm looking forward to doing that again here.

"I am positive about the team, but my players are positive too.

"We have great belief in our abilities. That's what we're going to try and express.

"In the Premier League we are a bit behind in terms of points, but internationally and domestically we are in a good position in the cups.

"If we had a few more points in the Premier League, then we wouldn't be talking like this.

"It's a very fine line between success and failure.

"This team has all the ability to play a very good game and show the qualities these players have."

"We are scoring goals and creating chances.

"We're averaging more than two a game in the matches I've had in charge. We also look strong and solid. I don't see a problem there.

"I'm quite confident about my team, to be honest. Everybody seems to have an opinion, and they have that right, but I disagree.

"I believe in my team, my squad, my players. I don't think we're weak, not at all.

"We have, still, many games to play in the Premier League to reach fourth, and two games in the quarter-finals of the Champions League. It looked a little gloomier two weeks ago, so we're pleased to be here."

On the team plane out to Portugal were former Chelsea chief executive Peter Kenyon, still "a friend" of the club and Queen drummer Roger Taylor, a Blues fan.

It must be hoped that, come the conclusion of this quarter-final, it is not a case of "Another One Bites the Dust."

pages.subdeck: THOUGHTFUL ... Owen Coyle
pages.headline: Cheers, Harry
pages.teaser: BUT the Bolton boss plans to repay him by ending Tottenham's Wembley dream
pages.articlebody:
OWEN COYLE has thanked Harry Redknapp for the outstanding support he showed during Fabrice Muamba's fight for life.

But the Bolton boss plans to repay him by ending Tottenham's Wembley dream at White Hart Lane tonight.

Coyle revealed the Spurs chief has been ringing him every day in the aftermath of midfielder Muamba's cardiac arrest. He is looking forward to showing his gratitude to Redknapp  but insists his team are going to North London to earn an FA Cup semi-final place.

The original tie was abandoned in horrific circumstances 10 days ago as Muamba collapsed 41 minutes into the game.

Coyle said: "It doesn't surprise me because I know the man he is anyway, but I've spoken to Harry two or three times a day since last week.

"That was while I was down there. But even when I came back and we both had games to prepare for, I spoke to him each day. That just sums up the man he is.

"He didn't have to be phoning two or three times a day for an update, but he had genuine concern and goodwill.

"From Daniel Levy as chairman all the way through the club, Tottenham Hotspur have been truly outstanding."

Coyle will lead a delegation from Wanderers to the London Chest Hospital today to visit Muamba, 23, who remains in a serious condition.

Two players are likely to go, with his close friends David Wheater, Gretar Steinsson and Sam Ricketts particularly keen to see him.

Coyle said: "There'll be a small representation at the family's request to come and see Fabrice.

"Then they can filter the news back to the lads  hopefully that he is continuing to improve. We'll try to progress to the semi-final. It's going to be emotional but I'll pick a team that can win."

Ricketts revealed Bolton's stars suffered with sickness and flashbacks after Muamba's collapse.

Coyle added: "I'll speak to them all and check they are ready to play. But we'll probably be very close to the team that took the field last time."

Coyle was buoyed by news Muamba had watched his team's 2-1 victory over Blackburn on Match of the Day.

He said: "He was able to watch it on Sunday. I'm led to believe he fell asleep when it was 2-0  I don't know if he still thinks we won 2-0.

"For those of us who were there on that Saturday night, to think that a week later he could sit up and watch some of that game is remarkable."

pages.subdeck: HAPPIER TIMES ... John Terry and Rom celebrate '05 FA Cup triumph
pages.headline: No Chmps Lge will be Rom hell
pages.teaser: IAN WRIGHT says the problems will pile up if Blues finish outside the top four
pages.articlebody:
ROMAN ABRAMOVICH has spent the last nine years chasing the Champions League trophy.

He has spent millions and changed numerous managers in his pursuit, so to not even qualify for the tournament next season would be catastrophic  and a complete embarrassment.

I see Chelsea beating Benfica over the two legs in their Champions League quarter-final.

As I said last week, neither Milan or Barcelona would fancy playing a Chelsea team inspired by an in-form Fernando Torres.

But, right now, I still think Chelsea could struggle to reach the final.

If Chelsea triumph in Munich on May 19, it would be the result of the century when you consider everything that has happened at the west London club over these last few months.

Instead, I think they will have to sort out their league form just to qualify for next season's Champions League.

Fair play to Petr Cech for being honest and admitting it would be "a lost season" if Chelsea are not in the competition next term.

We are always hearing players at big clubs coming out with the same old predictable lines, so I have great respect for Cech being honest.

He is right as Chelsea could face numerous problems if they fail to reach the Champions League.

It may be easy to entice players with a combination of big money and likely success.

Manchester City have the cash and now they can promise new signings the chance of likely silverware.

Chelsea have been in a similar situation over the years as they have paid huge sums to players who have also known they are guaranteed matches on the biggest stage in Europe.

So Chelsea will find themselves in an unusual position come the summer if they finish outside the top four.

The only reward for players going to Stamford Bridge would be big bucks  and that is not always enough.

Also, you get a certain type of top-class player who is prepared to sacrifice ambition in terms of not playing in the Champions League.

So everyone at Stamford Bridge could be facing their worst nightmare.

Chelsea will still be confident of catching Spurs because Harry Redknapp's side have gone off the boil.

The 0-0 draw with Chelsea made it five League games without a win so it's also testing times for Tottenham.

This is Redknapp's biggest battle since he took over at Spurs.

I believe Spurs have to beat Bolton in the FA Cup tonight and see off Swansea on Sunday to keep their season alive.

Tottenham do not have the experience at this stage of the season and this could be crucial in the battle for fourth.

When you look at Tottenham's impressive season  and they have played some outstanding football  it would be disastrous for Spurs to end up in a Europa League spot.

Maybe it is no coincidence that Tottenham's slump is at the same time as Redknapp (left) has emerged as an England target.

There is no way that Harry has taken his eye off the ball despite the interest in him taking over for Euro 2012.

Maybe other people within the team have become unsettled by the speculation.

For Harry's sake, I hope he can turn the season around. He deserves it.

It will be a tough game against Bolton at White Hart Lane after what happened in the first match. But it is terrific that Fabrice Muamba is making a steady recovery so I'm not sure the match will be as difficult for the players as some people suggest.

Yet, incredibly, Chelsea and Spurs are not the only teams to be struggling in this remarkable end to the season.

Kenny Dalglish is fortunate he has won a cup this season. Because all that is keeping him in a job is the Carling Cup and his reputation.

Liverpool have splashed out lots of money yet they could soon be below Swansea and Norwich in the table if they keep failing to pick up decent results.

Stoke are only four points behind and they are 12th in the Premier League.

Dalglish has spent all this cash yet there is not a great deal of quality within the squad.

I can see all his enthusiasm on the sidelines but something is not right. Something has to change.

Meanwhile, Arsenal keep on winning. I'm not sure anyone would have predicted the season would finish like this.

GOALKEEPER  CITY

DURING the early weeks of the season it was no contest as David De Gea struggled to find his feet in English football and Joe Hart looked in prime form.

United's Spanish keeper has closed the gap over the last few weeks but England's No 1 down at the Etihad still edges it.

DEFENCE  UNITED

CITY'S Europa League defeat in Lisbon has proved costly with first-choice pairing Joleon Lescott and Vincent Kompany both injured and yet to return.

United struggled initially after Nemanja Vidic was crocked but have coped well on the whole and look to have more options.

MIDFIELD  CITY

NO matter what Patrick Vieira says, bringing back Paul Scholes has proved to be inspired. He allows Alex Ferguson to shuffle his pack as he did last night.

City's midfield looked unstoppable at the start of the season but key men like Yaya Toure and David Silva are feeling the pace.

ATTACK  UNITED

ROBERTO MANCINI almost has an embarrassment of riches with Carlos Tevez back. But the goals have dried up for Mario Balotelli and Edin Dzeko, leaving the onus on Sergio Aguero.

Fergie does not have the same options but he does have Rooney hitting his straps.

MANAGER  UNITED

ONLY one winner here. Fergie's 12 Premier League titles makes him pretty much untouchable and he has largely kept his cool throughout.

Mancini won titles in Italy but it is fair to say he never had anyone quite like the veteran Scot breathing down his neck.

pages.headline: Arteta: No let-up
pages.teaser: THE Gunners have flown up the table with a sensational seven-game winning streak
pages.articlebody:
MIKEL ARTETA has warned Arsenal's flying stars not to take their foot off the gas.

The Gunners are on a sensational seven-game winning streak.

It has seen them build up a three-point cushion over Spurs in fourth  who they trailed by 10 points just five weeks ago.

Now Arteta, who scored in their 3-0 win over Aston Villa on Saturday, insists there must be no let-up.

The Spaniard said: "If anyone thinks it's all done now, then they are making a big mistake.

"We can't take our foot off the pedal now.

"We have won seven in a row now, which is very difficult in the Premier League nowadays, and we have done it well, playing some high-tempo football, but there are some tough, tough games coming up in our last eight matches."

Arsenal saw their Champions League hopes written off after a dismal start that saw them slip into the relegation places.

And Arteta is pleased that the Emirates fans finally have something to celebrate.

He added: "When you are winning, life is good and you can see that the fans are enjoying it at the moment.

"They deserve it as well because they were behind us when things weren't going right.

"Hopefully we can finish the season strongly because we have a group of players and staff who really mean business."

Arteta, a £10million summer capture from Everton, insists Arsenal dressing-room has stayed rock-solid  through the good times and the bad.

He said: "To be honest I was really surprised with the spirit when I came here  even when we were down it was so good.

"It is something you rely on because if you start blaming each other and shouting at each other it is not good.

"This group has always been positive, the manager has always been positive with the players and we have kept at it. We have the talent, we know we have the ability to win games and sometimes it is just about the balance in confidence.

"We have it all together now."

Meanwhile, Laurent Koscielnly looks likely to return for the Gunners for their London derby with QPR on Saturday.

He pulled out of the Villa win but boss Wenger said: "It was tendonitis.

"I don't think it's very bad. He woke up with big pain. We tried to push him to play but in the warm up he couldn't move.

"For the next game he should be all right."

DARREN FLETCHER has vowed to come back fitter and stronger from his illness nightmare.

The Manchester United star is suffering from an inflammatory bowel disease and has not played since November.

Fletcher, 27, is yet to even return to training.

The midfielder said: "I'm still not ready to come back playing or training yet but I'm listening to the medical people and trying to get myself right.

"The challenge and the focus is to be ready for next season.

"Me and the medical team decided it'd be best if I tried to get myself right and take an extended period out from the game; then come back fully fit and ready to play."

Fletcher has taken over some of Paul Scholes' coaching duties that were freed up when the veteran came out of retirement.

And the Scot added: "It's an unpredictable illness and you don't know what lies ahead of you.

"But I've got to keep staying strong and keep believing. That's an important side of it: positive thinking.

"I've received great support from everyone in Scotland and down in Manchester. I'm hopeful and really positive that I'll be back and back to my best."

ANDERS LINDEGAARD may not play again this season after a setback in his battle to come back from damaged ankle ligaments.

The Manchester United doctors expected keeper Lindegaard to be out for a month after the injury in a January training session.

But despite stepping up his comeback two weeks ago, Lindegaard is now back working with physios.

United are adamant they will not take any risks with the Dane, 27, and are working on building up the strength in his ankle.

Boss Alex Ferguson has been told there is no specific date for a return and Lindegaard is making slow progress.

The outstanding recent form of first choice David de Gea, with young Ben Amos impressing too, has also been a factor in United not trying to rush Lindegaard's return.

Lindegaard had started to establish himself as a regular when he landed awkwardly attempting to catch a cross in training.

In June, he is in line for a pay hike to £50,000 a week after his first full season, having joined from Norwegian side Aalesunds in January last year.

NICKLAS BENDTNER is eyeing FA Cup glory  even if he cannot see it right now.

The Dane leads the line against Everton in tonight's quarter-final replay still wearing a mask after fracturing his cheekbone in January.

Sunderland's on-loan Arsenal striker has bagged three goals in five games. And his form is more surprising as his face protector means he is unable to see everything going on.

He said: "I'll be wearing it on Tuesday but I can't see with it on. I give the ball away because I can't see sometimes.

"It's not good because sometimes if you see a run, your eye disappears in the mask so you are seeing out of the eye that can't see the run."

Bendtner, 24, headed the Black Cats in front in Saturday's 3-1 win over QPR. And he said: "It was the first header on target I've had wearing the mask."

Victory tonight will book a wembley semi-final date with Liverpool on April 14.

Bendtner added: "It will be difficult as Everton are a good team. We've got to fancy our chances though."

pages.articlebody:
DAVID MOYES has turned the heat up on FA Cup rivals Sunderland by claiming: The pressure is on you now.

Everton boss Moyes takes his men to the Stadium of Light tomorrow for their quarter-final replay.

And the Toffees boss said: "I think the pressure does go back on them. I felt it a little bit when we played at home.

"We tried to do the job and win here but it was a good result for Sunderland to get us back to the Stadium of Light.

"They will see a good part of the job has been done and they have probably got themselves in the favourites position because they have been very good at home under Martin, so we know it will be a tough game."

Victory for Moyes would tee up a semi-final blockbuster against local rivals Liverpool  the first Wembley trip for the Toffees since 2009.

And he said: "It would be great. It is something I would really look forward to.

"I really enjoyed the last time  except for the result  but it would be terrific if we could go and do it again.

"But I am not thinking or talking that way because I would rather try to play in this game and then see where we go from there.

"It is too soon to ask me a question about getting back to Wembley at the moment."

Everton's cup run has left Moyes complaining of a pile up of games.

And the Scot insists the Toffees have been left short-changed by the fixture computer.

Moyes added: "It will affect the squad but you have to take the games as they come.

"You have to get on with it but, as I've said a couple of times, I don't think it has been particularly fair on us.

"The Premier League have been hard on Everton this year, that is for sure."

pages.headline: Paul puts deals on hold
pages.teaser: CANARIES chief won't discuss new deals until Norwich make sure of their Prem Lge future
pages.articlebody:
NORWICH boss Paul Lambert is refusing to discuss any new contracts until his team are certain of staying in the Premier League.

The cautious Canaries boss insists his team are still not safe despite being 14 points clear of the relegation zone with just eight games remaining.

And that means a number of his out-of-contract stars are still not sure what the future might hold for them.

Midfielder David Fox says: "I guess we'll all just have to wait and see what the manager decides.

"The club has been in a very bad situation in the past money-wise so the manager is not in a position to be handing out big contracts and then we get relegated.

"The whole club has been doing things sensibly since we came to the Premier League and that's not going to change all of a sudden.

"I am sure people will find out when we are safe. There are others in my situation and we all have to wait and see what the manager wants to do with us."

pages.subdeck: WHO'S A NAUGHTY ROY THEN ... Hodgson has apologised
pages.headline: Hodgson armband apology
pages.teaser: THE Baggies boss ripped off his armband in frustration during defeat to Newcastle
pages.articlebody:
ROY HODGSON has been forced to apologise for 'shamefully' throwing away a black armband worn in memory of West Brom legend Ray Barlow.

The Baggies boss ripped off his armband in frustration and tossed it to the ground during Sunday's 3-1 defeat to Newcastle.

He was then slated by fans. One posted online: "Shame on you."

Hodgson said: "It's something I did without thinking out of frustration at conceding the third.

"I meant no disrespect to such a great player, nor his family, and offer my sincere apologies if it has caused offence.

"It was only right that Ray's family were invited pitch-side before kick-off for the minute's applause and I took this opportunity to pass on my personal condolences to them."

Barlow, who played 482 times for the club from 1946-1960, died 13 days ago aged 85.

pages.subdeck: IN THE SWING ... brilliant Anderson celebrates Dilshan scalp
pages.headline: Right Ander
pages.teaser: JAMES ANDERSON arrived among the greats yesterday by passing 250 Test wickets
pages.articlebody:
JAMES ANDERSON arrived among the greats yesterday when he became the first England bowler since Ian Botham to take 250 Test wickets.

The milestone showed beyond all doubt that Anderson is one of England's finest bowlers of any era.

But even the Lancashire swinger could not dislodge the brilliant, beguiling Mahela Jayawardene on day one of the First Test.

The Sri Lankan captain scored 168 not out of his team's 289-8  an innings of sublime class and easy style.

Without him, England would have been in a hugely dominant position and Jayawardene scored an incredible 58.1 per cent of his side's runs.

Jayawardene was helped, however, by four dropped catches  two of them embarrassingly bad by Monty Panesar, thrusting him right back to his days as a joke fielder.

Jayawardene is often overlooked when discussing the best batsmen of the modern era  the likes of Sachin Tendulkar, Brian Lara and Ricky Ponting receive more plaudits. But anyone who saw his dazzling century in last year's World Cup final knows he belongs in the same bracket.

This was another masterpiece of skill on a pitch that will only become more tricky for batting.

Even Anderson admitted: "It's one of the better Test innings I have seen. I don't think anyone else scored much above 20, so it was an incredible effort.

"Mahela had the knack of knowing when to go for a big shot and when to grind it out for a bit. The balance of his innings was brilliant."

During Anderson's dark times in the mid-2000s, he could never imagine he would overtake Darren Gough, Andrew Caddick, Steve Harmison, Matthew Hoggard and Andrew Flintoff as England's most prolific bowler of the modern era.

Anderson was on a hat-trick in only his second over. Lahiru Thiramanne edged a catch into Graeme Swann's safe hands at second slip.

That was wicket No 250 as he became only the sixth England bowler to reach the milestone and first since Botham got there in Perth in 1982. From Anderson's next delivery, the dangerous Kumar Sangakkara nicked off.

When Tillakaratne Dilshan perished in Stuart Broad's following over, Sri Lanka were 15-3 on a pitch where batting first was a massive advantage. Sri Lanka were forced to dig in but Jayawardene was happy to counter-attack, too, and deposited Swann's third ball of the day into the crowd.

Soon after lunch, Thilan Samaraweera strayed too far out of his ground at the non-striker's end and was run out when Anderson deflected a drive by Jayawardene on to the stumps.

Dinesh Chandimal's first scoring shot was a six but then he presented Samit Patel with his maiden Test wicket.

Patel, chosen ahead of Ravi Bopara, was thrilled when Chandimal's wild heave at his left-arm spin looped tamely to cover.

Who would have guessed that Swann and Panesar would send down 46 overs of spin between them without a wicket, while Patel would have two victims in his nine overs?

Anderson's third wicket arrived when Prasanna Jayawardene was lbw. It took his Test aggregate to 252 and level with the great Lancashire fast bowler of the 1950s Brian Statham  known as Gentleman George.

Anderson said: "It is a very nice milestone, something I can look back on when I eventually retire."

Jayawardene escaped on 64 when Anderson got a finger to a diving chance at slip. Then Anderson spilled a leaping caught-and-bowled opportunity on 90  and Mahela hit the next ball for six.

Panesar's two drops off Jayawardene were excruciating. They came in successive overs at long leg and mid-on  with the batsman on 147 and 154  and could yet cost England the match.

Anderson added: "We've focused on our catching on this trip, so it was very disappointing to drop some and a few of them weren't the most difficult.

"Everyone is upset when they drop catches. It took the shine off an otherwise good day for Monty. I thought he bowled really well."

pages.subdeck: SPYGATE ... Caterham team principal Tony Fernandes
pages.headline: Caterham embroiled in new spy row
pages.teaser: TONY FERNANDES' Caterham team could be hit with a multi-million pound fine from the FIA
pages.articlebody:
TONY FERNANDES' Formula One team, Caterham, could be hit with a multi-million pound fine from the sports' governing body, as the latest spy scandal rocks F1.

The row comes after a long-running legal dispute involving the Force India team, Caterham and Aerolab  an aerodynamic development company.

Aerolab worked with Force India up to July 2009 before switching to Caterham  then known as Lotus Racing  shortly after.

The claim was that Aerolab copied significant parts of Force India's car when helping designing the Lotus T127, the team's debut car that hit the track in 2010.

However, Mr Justice Arnold ruled last week that Force India had "come nowhere near" to proving their case, primarily ruling in Aerolab's favour over unpaid fees, amounting to £710,000.

However, there is a clause in the 122-page report that has angered the Marussia F1 team, who have now approached the FIA to take action against Caterham.

Paragraph 373 of the report reads: "In my judgment the Aerolab/FondTech CAD (computer-aided design) files do reproduce a substantial part of the corresponding Force India CAD files for the following parts: the vortex generator, rear brake duct lower element and rear view mirror."

Both Force India and Marussia believe this is an infringement of the FIA's International Sporting Code, pertinently Article 151c which refers to 'any fraudulent conduct or act prejudicial to the interests of any competition or to the interests of motor sport generally'.

This is the same article which formed the basis of the "spygate" sage in 2007 when McLaren were hit with a whopping £49million fine for having confidential information belonging to Ferrari.

As well of the threat of a hefty fine, QPR owner Fernandes could see his team's results expunged from the record books.

Mr Justice Arnold's report has left Marussia "outraged" and they have written a letter to the FIA to ask them to investigate.

Marussia's sporting director Graeme Lowdon said: "If a team that we've been competing against has had access to confidential intellectual property owned by another team for any significant component on the car, then we would quite rightly be outraged.

"It's in breach of the rules. It's fundamental to this sport that we all abide by the regulations we all sign up to.

"The court case between Caterham and Force India has clearly been a very complicated one.

"But from our point of view, we're less interested in the overall pros and cons of the individual issues of the different parties involved.

"The key thing for us is that in the judgment itself there seems to be a quite clear reference to an infringement of copyright and that has us extremely concerned as a team competing in the championship.

"We're in communication with the FIA on the matter and we have every confidence that the FIA can deal with these matters in the correct way.

"We have no reason to believe that that won't happen.

Lowdon added: "The rules of the sport are very complicated. But there is a fundamental premise in Formula One as it currently operates that every entrant is a constructor.

"And there are very clear definitions of what a constructor is.

"The basic principle is that you design and or own the intellectual property of various key parts to the car that you compete with. It's very, very fundamental to the sport.

"Without those safeguards we would not have a level playing field and it would not be the Formula One world championship we understand it to be."

pages.subdeck: TENSE SHOOTOUT ... Nathan Robertson
pages.headline: Nathan sweating on final Olympics
pages.teaser: BADMINTON ace, a big hit with Gail Emms, sweats on 2012 qualifying with Jenny Wallwork
pages.articlebody:
NATHAN ROBERTSON admits his glittering career would be marred if he misses the cut for London 2012.

The badminton ace won Olympic silver in 2004 and world championship gold in 2006 with former partner Gail Emms.

Robertson, 34, is a veteran of three Games and looked a cert to qualify with Jenny Wallwork in the mixed doubles.

But a slump in form and the emergence of Chris Adcock and Imogen Bankier has left them facing a tense shootout.

The one Olympic spot will go to the pair who are ranked highest in the world on May 3.

Robertson and Wallwork slumped to 22nd last week but responded by winning the Polish International tournament on Sunday.

The last ranking left them 10 places behind Adcock and Bankier, world silver medallists last year.

Robertson, who will retire this year, said: "All focus is on London, trying to attain that perfect ending to my career. But it's going to be tough. If I don't make it, it will be a huge disappointment right at the end of my career.

"I'm sure when I look back it will be with incredible memories, having achieved everything I wanted from the game  except that Olympic gold.

"It's tough at the moment after a mid-season blip when the stress of qualifying played its part.

"I'm sure it was the Olympic pressures which caused the blip.

"You know you're competing for a place and there are so few available. Plus the expectation you put on yourself.

"But, on the other hand, there are a lot of people who would gladly exchange with me and be on the edge of qualifying for London."

Just 18 months ago, Robertson and Wallwork were not only the top British pair but they were also established in the world's top 10.

He added: "It has been fantastic for me to achieve three previous Olympics and to be very comfortable in the qualifying.

"Partnerships only work when both players are confident. It's very tough when the stress takes over."
